January  – An -year-old Henry VIII jousts anonymously at Richmond, Surrey and draws applause, before revealing his identity.

January  – The Mary Rose ship is laid out. The next year the ship is launched on July , , and is afterwards towed to London to be fitted, and is finally completed in . In , during the Battle of the Solent, she sank. The reason for her sinking is disputed with contemporary accounts claiming the ship was heeled over or sank by French ships with gunfire, although modern historians believe it was sunk due to being unstable.
January  – Catherine of Aragon gives birth to her first child, and the first known child of King Henry VIII, a stillborn daughter.
February  – Peace treaty concluded between Pope Julius II and the Republic of Venice.
February  – In Rome, Pope Julius II revokes the interdict, imposed on the Republic of Venice in .

January  – The Siege of Mirandola by the Papal States, with help from the Duchy of Urbino and Spanish and Venetian troops, ends with the capture of Mirandola after  days of fighting. The Pope personally leads the troops and, after the outnumbered defenders surrender, works at preventing his troops from pillaging the city or harming the residents.

February  – King Henry VIII of England opens the two-day Westminster Tournament to celebrate the birth (on January ) of his son Prince Henry. Sadly, the infant prince dies on February , nine days after the tournament's end. The festivities are later memorialized in the  Westminster Tournament Roll, a series of  separately painted pictures stitched together to form a roll almost  feet ( m) long and ⁄ inches (. cm) wide.
February  – (9th waning of Tabaung  ME In what is now Myanmar, King Shwenankyawshin Narapati II of Ava dedicates his "exquisite golden palace".

February  – In Italy, on "Fat Thursday", a Christian celebration marking the last days of feasting before the period of fasting during the Roman Catholic Lent, discontented citizens of Friuli stage a revolt against their Venetian occupiers and attack the city of Udine and invade the palaces of several members of nobility, murdering the wealthy families and plundering the palace contents. Special troops arrive from Gradisca d'Isonzo on March  and suppress the rebellion.
March  – On the island of Puerto Rico, Spanish conquistador Juan Ponce de León leads an incursion at Yahuecas against the local Taino warriors, commanded by Chief Urayoán.
January  – Svante Nilsson, regent of Sweden since , dies at the age of . Eric Trolle is subsequently elected as the new Regent, but will be ousted after only six months.
January  – Neagoe Basarab becomes the new Prince of Wallachia at the capital, Târgoviște, after Prince Prince Vlad V is captured at battle in Bucharest and then decapitated.
February  – War of the League of Cambrai: The French carry out the Sack of Brescia.
March  – Pope Julius II issues the papal bull Dilecte fili, declaring King Louis XII deposed and directing that the French throne be given to King Henry VIII of England.
March  – Donyo Dorje, ruler of the Kingdom of Ü-Tsang and most of Tibet, dies after a reign of more than  years and is succeeded by his brother, Ngawang Namgyal.

January  – Spanish conquistador Vasco Núñez de Balboa writes a letter to King Ferdinand II of Aragon advocating genocide against the native peoples of on the Caribbean islands, and begins the killing of hundreds of residents of Caribbean villages.

February  – Pope Julius II issues the papal bull Exigit contumaciam, declaring queen Catherine of Navarre and king John III of Navarre to be heretics for their refusal to participate with other Roman Catholic nations in the anti-French Holy League of .
February  – Hans, King of Denmark dies at the age of  from injuries sustained in being thrown from a horse. He is succeeded by his -year-old son Christian II as ruler of Denmark-Norway.
February  – Pope Julius II dies in Rome.

March  – The conclave of the Roman Catholic Cardinals begins at the Niccoline Chapel in the Apostolic Palace in Rome, with  of the  Cardinals participating. In the first round of balloting, none of the Cardinals receives the required  votes necessary for a three-fourth's majority, though Cardinal Jaime Serra I Cau of Spain, Bishop of Albano, receives .
January  – A great fire breaks out, in the Rialto of Venice.

February  – War of the League of Cambrai: In what is now the Italian region of Friuli-Venezia Giulia, Giacomo Badoer, administrator of the Republic of Venice, orders a retreat from the approaching forces of the Holy Roman Empire, abandoning Udine, Cividale and Cormons and falling back on Sacile.
March  – A huge exotic embassy sent by King Manuel I of Portugal to Pope Leo X arrives in Rome, including Hanno, an Indian elephant.
March  – Louis XII of France makes peace with Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor.

April  – After a month of negotiations at Linz between the Holy Roman Empire and the Kingdom of Denmark, representatives of the two nations sign an alliance agreement, to be secured by the  marriage of the Emperor's -year-old daughter Isabella, to the new King of Denmark, Christian II, along with payment of a dowry to King Christian of , Rhenish gulden, equivalent to $,, USD  years later.
January  - King Louis XII of France dies of severe gout after a reign of  years, and his son-in-law, François, inherits the throne.
January  – François, is crowned King of France in the Cathedral of Reims, with his wife Claude, daughter of the late King Louis XII, crowned as Queen consort.
January - In Vietnam, an uprising led by Phùng Chương broke out in Tam Đảo and was quickly quelled by general Trịnh Duy Sản under emperor Lê Tương Dực of the Lê dynasty.
February  – King Henry VIII of England opens the English Parliament. Henry's chief advisor, Sir Thomas Nevill, is elected Speaker of the House of Commons
February  – George of Kratovo, a silversmith in Serbia, becomes a martyr to the Christian faith as he is burned to death on a pyre for refusing to convert to Islam.

January  – Juan Díaz de Solís arrives in what is now Punta del Este in Uruguay, where he becomes the first European to sail into the Río de la Plata (in future Argentina).  Díaz and nine of his men are attacked and killed by the local Charrúa people shortly after their arrival. although there was likely an expedition earlier in - by João de Lisboa and Estevão de Fróis.

January  – With the death of Ferdinand II of Aragon, his grandson, Charles of Ghent, becomes King of Spain; his mother Queen Joanna of Castile also succeeds as Queen of Aragon and co-monarch with Carlos, but remains confined at Tordesillas.

February  – After two months in Bologna, part of the Papal States in Italy, Pope Leo X concludes two months of negotiation with King François I of France. Their talks result in the abrogation of the French Pragmatic Sanction, and the conclusion of a new Concordat between the Papacy and France.
February  – Sir Edward Poynings becomes England's ambassador to Spain a second time and meets with King Carlos I to negotiate a treaty.

February  – In his capacity as Lord of Ireland, Henry VIII opens the first of six assemblies of parliament during his reign of the Parliament of Ireland at Dublin. The parliament holds three sessions, ending on October , when it is dismissed.
January  – Battle of Ridaniya: The Holy Ottoman army of the sultan Selim I defeats the Mamluk army in Egypt, commanded by the king Tuman Bay II.

January  – Cairo is captured by the Ottoman Empire after a three day battle, and the Mamluk Sultanate falls. The Abbasid Caliphate, reestablished in , falls to the Ottomans and the last Caliph, Al-Mutawakkil III, is deported along with his family to Constantinople.
February  – The Ottoman Sultan Selim I makes a triumphant entry into Cairo after his Janissaries have cleared the area of the Mamluk defenders.

February  – Bernal Díaz del Castillo, a chronicler who documents the conquest of Mexico, sets out with the Hernández de Córdoba expedition from Jaruco. They arrive at Cape Catoche twenty-one days later, and are met with hostility by the natives. Henry's -year-old sister Anne of Navarre serves as the regent until , when Henry reaches the age of majority.

February  – At the age of , Henry II becomes the King of Navarre, by then limited to the part of the Iberian peninsula north of the Pyrennes, upon the death of his mother, Queen Catherine in the capital, Pamplona.
January  – Piri Mehmed Pasha is appointed as the new Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire by the Sultan Selim I, replacing Yunus Pasha, who was executed four months earlier on September .

January  – Sir John Ernley is selected as the new Chief Justice of the Common Pleas of England by King King Henry VIII to replace the late Robert Rede, who died on January . Emley. He is replaced as Attorney General for England and Wales by John FitzJames.

February  – In Valladolid in Spain, Frenchman Jean Sauvage, Chancellor of Burgundy is appointed by Spain's Prince Charles as the Chief Judge of the Cortes of Valladolid. The choice of a foreigner is resented by the members of the court and Sauvage is replaced at the Cortes by the Spanish Bishop Pedro Ruiz de la Mota.
March  – The Dutch priest Erasmus of Rotterdam sends the new Ninety-five Theses of Martin Luther to England, delivering the Protestant manifesto to Sir Thomas More.

March  – King Charles of Spain gives his approval for the Magellan expedition, initially for the purpose of finding a westward route from Spain to the "Spice Islands" (now the Maluku Islands in Indonesia), to avoid the more frequently-used eastward route around Africa. Veteran seaman Ferdinand Magellan and navigator Rui Faleiro, both of Portugal, had turned to Spain to fund the expedition after being refused by King Manuel of Portugal. The voyage proves to be further than expected and becomes the first to sail around the world.
January  – Ulrich Zwingli preaches for the first time, as people's priest of the Great Minister in Zurich.

January  – Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor, dies at the age of  after a reign of slightly less than  years. An imperial election by the leaders of the various member states of the Empire is scheduled for June .
February  – The Spanish conquistador Hernán Cortés and his conquistadores depart from Cuba toward the island of Cozumel in Mexico to begin a mission of conquest.

February  – Because of the large population of Jews included converts to Christianity ("New Christians") in the colony of Portuguese India at Goa, King Manuel I of Portugal announces that there will be no further appointment of New Christians to government offices, but affirms that those already in office are not to be dismissed
March  – Hernán Cortés and his conquistadores land in Mexico.

January  – King Christian II of Denmark and Norway defeats the Swedes, at Lake Åsunden in Sweden. The Swedish regent Sten Sture the Younger is mortally wounded in the Battle of Bogesund. He is rushed towards Stockholm, in order to lead the fight against the Danes from there.
February  – Swedish regent Sten Sture dies from his wounds leaving a vacancy on the throne that allows King Christian II of Denmark to conquer Sweden within eight months.
February  – The Swabian League sells the Duchy of Württemberg to the Holy Roman Emperor, Charles V, for , florins and payment of the Duchy's debt of ,, Goldgulden
March  – Thomas Howard, 3rd Duke of Norfolk becomes England's new Lord Deputy of Ireland

March  – The Magellan expedition, led by Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan (Fernão de Magalhães), pauses in its attempt to sail around the world, stopping at Puerto San Julian on the lower east coast of what is now Patagonia in Argentina. His fleet consists of Magellan's flagship, Trinidad, and four other vessels, Concepción, Victoria, San Antonio and Santiago.
End of Fifteenth dynasty of Egypt.
Jacob migrates to Egypt, settling in the Land of Goshen, according to the Hebrew calendar.
April —Lunar Saros  begins.
January  – Pope Leo X excommunicates Martin Luther, in the papal bull Decet Romanum Pontificem.
January  – Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, opens the Diet of Worms in Worms, Germany.
January  – Suleiman the Magnificent suppresses a revolt by the ruler of Damascus, Janbirdi al-Ghazali.
February  – The Nydala Abbey Bloodbath takes place at Nydala Abbey, Sweden; the abbot and many monks are murdered by Danes.

March 
Ferdinand Magellan makes the first European contact with Guam, most likely landing in Tumon.
Martin Luther is summoned to appear before the Diet of Worms.
End of Fifteenth dynasty of Egypt.
Jacob migrates to Egypt, settling in the Land of Goshen, according to the Hebrew calendar.
April —Lunar Saros  begins.

January  – The papal conclave to elect a successor to the late Pope Leo X is concluded as Adriaan Florensz Boeyens of the Netherlands, Bishop of Utrecht, is selected as a compromise candidate despite being absent from the proceedings. Bishop Boeyens is proclaimed as Pope Adrian VI, the 218th pope and the last non-Italian pontiff for the next  years.

January  – Spanish conquistador Gil González Dávila sets out from the gulf of Panama to explore the Pacific coast of Central America. He explores Nicaragua and names Costa Rica when he finds copious quantities of gold in Pacific beaches.

February  – In Castile in Spain, the Revolt of the Comuneros is re-ignited when King Carlos V reneges on a promised amnesty to participants in a  uprising, and threatens to execute revolt leader María Pacheco. Calm is restored by the intervention of Maria de Mendoza, and while many of the rebels are punished, Pacheco is able to escape to Portugal.

February  – The Pact of Brussels is signed between Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor and his younger brother Archduke Ferdinand, guaranteeing Charles's support of Ferdinand to become the King of the Romans.

February  – The Grünwald Conference takes place in the Duchy of Bavaria in Germany, as the co-rulers, Duke Wilhelm IV and Duke Ludwig X agreed to retain the traditional Roman Catholic Church but to make their own reformation of the church within the Duchy, beginning what will eventually become the Counter-Reformation.
End of Fifteenth dynasty of Egypt.
Jacob migrates to Egypt, settling in the Land of Goshen, according to the Hebrew calendar.
April —Lunar Saros  begins.

January  – Christian II is forced to abdicate as King of Denmark and Norway after the nobles of the herredag at Viborg have renounced their allegiance in favor of his uncle, Frederick, Duke of Holstein. Christian is exiled to the Netherlands in April.
February  – Construction of Fort Kastela by Portuguese invaders, on what is now the island of Ternate in Indonesia, is completed as Portugal claims the Spice Islands (now the Maluku Islands).

February  – Battle of al-Shihr on the Arabian Peninsula (in what is now Yemen): Troops from Portugal fight  against the Kathiri Sultanate, ruled by the Emir Mutran bin Mansur. After a battle of one day, the Portuguese sack the capital, Al-Shihr, and establish a port on the Indian Ocean.
February  – Captain Antón Mayor formally claims for Spain what is now Nicaragua, after he arrives with Andrés Niño and other Spanish troops on the Central American coast at El Realejo.

March  – In Spain's Kingdom of Valencia, a rebellion by the Brotherhoods of Mallorca is suppressed after two years, as the rebels surrender their capital, Palma de Mallorca, to Spanish and German troops.
End of Fifteenth dynasty of Egypt.
Jacob migrates to Egypt, settling in the Land of Goshen, according to the Hebrew calendar.
April —Lunar Saros  begins.

January  – Florentine explorer Giovanni da Verrazzano, on board La Dauphine in the service of Francis I of France, sets out from Madeira for the New World, to seek out a western sea route to the Pacific Ocean.

February  – Tecun Uman, the K'iche' Maya ruler of Guatemala's highlands, is killed in a battle near Quetzaltenango between the K'iche' Maya people and the invading Spanish conquistadors led by Pedro Alvarado.
March  – Spanish conquistador Pedro de Alvarado destroys the Kʼicheʼ kingdom of Qʼumarkaj, taking the capital, Quiché.
March  – da Verrazzano's expedition makes landfall at Cape Fear at what is later the U.S. state of North Carolina.
April  – Verrazzano's expedition makes the first European entry into New York Bay, and sights the island of Manhattan.
End of Fifteenth dynasty of Egypt.
Jacob migrates to Egypt, settling in the Land of Goshen, according to the Hebrew calendar.
April —Lunar Saros  begins.

January  – The Anabaptist Movement is born when Conrad Grebel, Felix Manz, George Blaurock, and about a dozen others baptize each other in the home of Manz's mother on Neustadt-Gasse, Zürich, breaking a thousand-year tradition of church-state union.

February  – Battle of Pavia: German and Spanish forces under Charles de Lannoy and the Marquis of Pescara defeat the French army, and capture Francis I of France, after his horse is wounded by Cesare Hercolani. While Francis is imprisoned in Lombardy and then transferred to Madrid, the first attempts to form a Franco-Ottoman alliance with Suleiman the Magnificent against the Habsburg Empire are made.
February  – The last Aztec Emperor, Cuauhtémoc, is killed by Hernán Cortés.

March  – In the German town of Memmingen, the pamphlet The Twelve Articles: The Just and Fundamental Articles of All the Peasantry and Tenants of Spiritual and Temporal Powers by Whom They Think Themselves Oppressed is published, the first human rights related document written in Europe.

April  – German Peasants' War in the Holy Roman Empire: Battle of Leipheim – The peasants suffer great losses when they are attacked by Georg, Truchsess von Waldburg and the town of Leipheim is forced to surrender. Four peasant leaders are beheaded, including Jakob Wehe and Ulrich Schoen.
End of Fifteenth dynasty of Egypt.
Jacob migrates to Egypt, settling in the Land of Goshen, according to the Hebrew calendar.
April —Lunar Saros  begins.

January  – Treaty of Madrid: Peace is declared between Francis I of France and Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor. Francis agrees to cede Burgundy and abandons all claims to Flanders, Artois, Naples, and Milan.

January  – The deadline for Spanish Muslims to convert to Christianity or leave is reached in the Crown of Aragon and the Principality of Catalonia as decreed by the edict of November  by Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor acting in his capacity as King of Spain. The deadline for the Kingdom of Valencia had passed on December , .
February  – Suleiman the Magnificent, Sultan of the Ottoman Empire, agrees to form a military alliance with France, after King François I sends a proposal by way of his envoy, Jean Frangipani.

February  – In Guatemala, a group of  deserters from the Spanish colonial army destroy Iximche, the capital of the indigenous kingdom of the Mayan Kaqchikel people, and burn the palace of the Ahpo Xahil
February  – Spanish author Gonzalo Fernández de Oviedo y Valdés, commonly called "Oviedo", publishes the chronicle La Natural Hystoria De Las Indias (The Natural History of the Indies)
End of Fifteenth dynasty of Egypt.
Jacob migrates to Egypt, settling in the Land of Goshen, according to the Hebrew calendar.
April —Lunar Saros  begins.
January  – Croatian nobles elect Ferdinand I of Austria as King of Croatia in the Parliament on Cetin.
January  – Felix Manz, co-founder of the Swiss Anabaptists, is drowned in the Limmat in Zürich by the Zürich Reformed state church.

February  – Queen consort Mary of Hungary, named as regent for the kingdom upon the August  death of her husband Louis II, asks permission from the Hungarian Diet to step down as the regent for the newly elected Frederick of Habsburg, but is denied.
February  – The Mughal–Rajput wars begin in India between the Emperor Babur of the Mughal Empire and states of the Rajput Confederacy, with the victory of the Rajput faction at the Battle of Bayana.

February  –
Ferdinand of the House of Habsburg is formally crowned as King of Bohemia at Pressburg (now Bratislava in Slovakia).
The seven articles of the Schleitheim Confession are formally adopted by the Mennonite Anabaptist Christians at Schleitheim in the Canton of Schaffhausen in Switzerland.
End of Fifteenth dynasty of Egypt.
Jacob migrates to Egypt, settling in the Land of Goshen, according to the Hebrew calendar.
April —Lunar Saros  begins.
January  – Gustav I of Sweden is crowned king of Sweden, having already reigned since his election in June .
January  – The Canton of Bern becomes the second in Switzerland to officially adopt Protestantism after -day debate, the Bern Disputation

February  – John Zápolya, ruler of the remaining eastern portion of Hungary after its the acquisition of the western section by the Habsburg Austrians, joins in an alliance with the Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent of the Ottoman Turks, receiving protection and autonomy in return for allowing Turkish occupation of his Eastern Hungarian Kingdom.

February
Peasant uprising in Dalarna, Sweden: The rebel campaign fails, and the rebel leader, later known as Daljunkern, flees to Rostock.
Diego García de Moguer explores the Sierra de la Plata along the Río de la Plata, and begins to travel up the Paraná River.
Peasant uprising in Dalarna, Sweden: The rebel campaign fails, and the rebel leader, later known as Daljunkern, flees to Rostock.
End of Fifteenth dynasty of Egypt.
Jacob migrates to Egypt, settling in the Land of Goshen, according to the Hebrew calendar.
April —Lunar Saros  begins.

January  – Basarab VI is installed as the new Prince of Wallachia (now in Romania) in the capital at Târgoviște, days after the assassination of the Voivode Radu of Afumați by the other boyars (Wallachian nobles). Basarab's reign lasts only a month and he is removed on February .
January  – Zhang Qijie becomes the most powerful woman in Ming dynasty China as the primary wife of the Jiajing Emperor, shortly after the death of the Empress Xiaojiesu.
January  – In India, the Mughal Emperor Babur departs from the capital at Agra toward Ghazipur to fight the Rajputs and the rebel Afghans who had captured the city.

January  – Peter Vannes, the Italian-born envoy for England's King Henry VIII, arrives in Rome on a mission to get Pope Clement VII to give a dispensation for King Henry to divorce one wife and marry another, with both marriages to be declared valid. The mission fails.
February  – The Örebro Synod provides the theological foundation of the Swedish Reformation, following the economic foundation of it, after the Reduction of Gustav I of Sweden.
End of Fifteenth dynasty of Egypt.
Jacob migrates to Egypt, settling in the Land of Goshen, according to the Hebrew calendar.
April —Lunar Saros  begins.
January  –  Strasbourg joins the Christliches Burgrecht, the Protestant alliance of Swiss cities.

January  – Sent on a mission to penetrate the interior of Mexico and to conquer the Kingdom of Michoacán, the Spanish conquistador Hernán Cortés leads a group of soldiers across the Lerma river through Cuitzeo and proceeds northwest. They arrive at Tonalá on March  and then take possession of the regions south of the Santiago River and north and west of Lake Chapala.

January  – Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, issues letters from his winter residence in Bologna, inviting members of the Imperial Diet to convene at Augsburg on April  to discuss various theological questions.
February  – Tangaxuan II, last cazonci of the Purépecha Empire, is executed by conquistador Nuño de Guzmán, ending the Purépecha Empire's independence from Spain.
February  – Charles V is crowned emperor in Bologna, by Pope Clement VII.
End of Seventeenth Dynasty of Egypt, start of the Eighteenth Dynasty.
Approximate first use of the Valley of the Kings.
The oldest dated star chart was made in Ancient Egypt.
Joseph interprets dreams of the Pharaoh, is released from prison and becomes second in Egypt next only to the Pharaoh himself.
End of the First Dynasty of Babylon and the start of the Kassite Dynasty—see History of Iraq.
January  – The third session of the Reformation Parliament of King Henry VIII of England is opened.
January  –  Lisbon earthquake: More than , people are killed in Portugal in an earthquake and subsequent tsunami.
February  – Lutheran princes in the Holy Roman Empire form an alliance known as the Schmalkaldic League.
February or March – Battle of Antukyah: Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi of the Adal Sultanate defeats the Ethiopian army.
March  – In India, the fortress of Mandu, capital of the Malwa Sultanate, falls as Malwa's Sultan Mahmúd II and his sons surrender to Bahadur Shah of Gujarat.
End of Seventeenth Dynasty of Egypt, start of the Eighteenth Dynasty.
Approximate first use of the Valley of the Kings.
The oldest dated star chart was made in Ancient Egypt.
Joseph interprets dreams of the Pharaoh, is released from prison and becomes second in Egypt next only to the Pharaoh himself.
End of the First Dynasty of Babylon and the start of the Kassite Dynasty—see History of Iraq.
January  – São Vicente is established as the first permanent Portuguese settlement in Brazil.

February  – The Deceived Ones (Gl'ingannati), a stage comedy written collectively by the Accademia degli Intronati in Siena, makes its debut as part of the festivities of the Italian city's annual carnival.

February  – William Warham, the -year-old Roman Catholic Archbishop of Canterbury, publicly declares that he is disasocciating himself from all acts of the English Parliament that are prejudicial to papal authority.

March  – The Supplication against the Ordinaries is presented to Henry VIII by Thomas More the Speaker of the House of Commons. Henry responds by stating that the Commons could hardly expect such consideration after they refused to assent to the government's proposals. Shortly afterwards, Parliament is prorogued until April .

April  – The democratic government of the Republic of Florence in Italy, in existence for more than  years since its founding in , is abolished by order of Pope Clement VII in order for a hereditary, and absolute, monarchy to be established. Alessandro de' Medici, Duke of Florence, the illegitimate son of Pope Clement, is given full power and the Republic's parliament (the Signoria) and the rule of the executive officer, the Gonfaloniere, come to an end.
End of Seventeenth Dynasty of Egypt, start of the Eighteenth Dynasty.
Approximate first use of the Valley of the Kings.
The oldest dated star chart was made in Ancient Egypt.
Joseph interprets dreams of the Pharaoh, is released from prison and becomes second in Egypt next only to the Pharaoh himself.
End of the First Dynasty of Babylon and the start of the Kassite Dynasty—see History of Iraq.
January  – King Henry VIII of England formally but secretly marries Anne Boleyn, who becomes his second queen consort.
January  – Thomas Audley, 1st Baron Audley of Walden, is appointed Lord Chancellor of England.
February  – The Reformation Parliament  is summoned into session by King Henry VIII of England, and meets until April .
February  – (15th waxing of Tabaung  ME) King Min Bin of Burma begins receiving tributes from the local lords of Bengal.
February  – By a treaty between the German city of Münster and the Holy Roman Empire, Münster is recognized as a Lutheran city.
End of Seventeenth Dynasty of Egypt, start of the Eighteenth Dynasty.
Approximate first use of the Valley of the Kings.
The oldest dated star chart was made in Ancient Egypt.
Joseph interprets dreams of the Pharaoh, is released from prison and becomes second in Egypt next only to the Pharaoh himself.
End of the First Dynasty of Babylon and the start of the Kassite Dynasty—see History of Iraq.

January  – The Parliament of England passes the Act Respecting the Oath to the Succession, recognising the marriage of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn, and their children as the legitimate heirs to the throne.
February  – A group of Anabaptists, led by Jan Matthys, seize Münster, Westphalia and declare it The New Jerusalem, begin to exile dissenters, and forcibly baptize all others.
March  – The Portuguese crown divides Colonial Brazil into fifteen donatory captaincies, hereditary titles similar to duchies.

March  – The Submission of the Clergy Act  becomes law in England, requiring submission of the clergy, that is, churchmen are to submit to the king and the publication of ecclesiastical laws without royal permission is forbidden.

April  (Easter Sunday) – Anabaptist Jan Matthys is killed by the Landsknechte, who laid siege to Münster on the day he predicted as the Second Coming of Christ. His follower John of Leiden takes control of the city.
End of Seventeenth Dynasty of Egypt, start of the Eighteenth Dynasty.
Approximate first use of the Valley of the Kings.
The oldest dated star chart was made in Ancient Egypt.
Joseph interprets dreams of the Pharaoh, is released from prison and becomes second in Egypt next only to the Pharaoh himself.
End of the First Dynasty of Babylon and the start of the Kassite Dynasty—see History of Iraq.
January  – Lima, now the capital of Peru, is founded by Francisco Pizarro, as Ciudad de los Reyes.

January  – The French Protestant leaders of the October  Affaire des Placards are burned to death in front of the Cathedral of Notre-Dame de Paris and witnessed by a large crowd that includes King François and the visiting Ottoman diplomats.
February  – George Joye publishes his Apologye in Antwerp, to clear his name from the accusations of William Tyndale.
March  – Fray Tomás de Berlanga discovers the Galápagos Islands, when blown off course en route to Peru.

March  – English forces under William Skeffington storm Maynooth Castle in Ireland, the stronghold of Thomas FitzGerald, 10th Earl of Kildare, after a siege that began on March . Skeffington shows little mercy to the  surviving defenders, and has them decapitated in front of the castle two days after the surrender.
End of Seventeenth Dynasty of Egypt, start of the Eighteenth Dynasty.
Approximate first use of the Valley of the Kings.
The oldest dated star chart was made in Ancient Egypt.
Joseph interprets dreams of the Pharaoh, is released from prison and becomes second in Egypt next only to the Pharaoh himself.
End of the First Dynasty of Babylon and the start of the Kassite Dynasty—see History of Iraq.
January  – The Colegio de Santa Cruz de Tlatelolco, the oldest European school of higher learning in the Americas, is established by Franciscans in Mexico City.
January  – John of Leiden, Bernhard Knipperdolling and Bernhard Krechting are executed in Münster for their roles in the Münster Rebellion.

January  – King Henry VIII of England is seriously injured when he falls from his horse at a jousting tournament in Greenwich, after which the fully armored horse falls on him. The King is unconscious for two hours, sustaining an injury to an ulcerated leg and a concussion.
February  – Spanish conquistador Pedro de Mendoza founds Buenos Aires in what is now Argentina.

February  – A Franco-Ottoman alliance exempts French merchants from Ottoman law and allows them to travel, buy and sell throughout the sultan's dominions, and to pay low customs duties on French imports and exports. The compact is confirmed in .
End of Seventeenth Dynasty of Egypt, start of the Eighteenth Dynasty.
Approximate first use of the Valley of the Kings.
The oldest dated star chart was made in Ancient Egypt.
Joseph interprets dreams of the Pharaoh, is released from prison and becomes second in Egypt next only to the Pharaoh himself.
End of the First Dynasty of Babylon and the start of the Kassite Dynasty—see History of Iraq.

January  – Princess Madeleine of Valois, the -year-old daughter of François I, King of France, is married to King James V of Scotland in a ceremony at the cathedral of Notre-Dame de Paris. Already in ill health at the time of the marriage, Madaleine lives only six more months before dying at the Holyrood Palace in Edinburgh on July .

January  – Alessandro de' Medici, Duke of Florence is assassinated by Lorenzino de' Medici, a distant cousin, who claims that he wants to reintroduce republican rule but has to flee to Venice. Instead Cosimo I of the junior branch of the Medici becomes the new duke.

January  – Bigod's Rebellion, an uprising by Roman Catholics, led by Francis Bigod against Henry VIII of England and Protestant Rebellion, begins with an unsuccessful attempt to seize Scarborough Castle in Yorkshire.

January  –  Most of Bigod's forces are captured by the English Army at a dawn raid of their camp at Beverley, Yorkshire, but Bigod escapes to Mulgrave and then to what is then the County of Cumberland.
January – At the battle of Ollantaytambo, the Inca Emperor Manco Inca Yupanqui defeats the Spanish led by Hernando Pizarro and the Spaniards' Indian allies
End of Seventeenth Dynasty of Egypt, start of the Eighteenth Dynasty.
Approximate first use of the Valley of the Kings.
The oldest dated star chart was made in Ancient Egypt.
Joseph interprets dreams of the Pharaoh, is released from prison and becomes second in Egypt next only to the Pharaoh himself.
End of the First Dynasty of Babylon and the start of the Kassite Dynasty—see History of Iraq.

January  – Leonard Grey, England's Lord Deputy of Ireland, successfully negotiates a truce in the semi-independent County Laois, formerly an Irish Kingdom, over the areas leadership.  between Peter O'Moore and Rory Lysaght.

January  – General Johann Katzianer of the Holy Roman Empire, on trial in Vienna for the disastrous Imperial campaign against the Ottoman Empire and for desertion during the Battle of Gorjani, escapes and flees to Kostajnica Fortress in Ottoman-controlled Croatia. After  months, Nikola IV Zrinski has Katzianer murdered.

February  – The Holy League, an alliance of Christian nations (the Papal States and the Republic of Venice, the Knights Hospitaller of Malta, Spain and the Spanish-ruled Viceroyalty of Naples and Sicily), is agreed upon under the direction of Pope Paul III and Venetian Senator Alvise Badoer.

February  – Treaty of Nagyvárad: Peace is declared between Ferdinand I, future Holy Roman Emperor and the Ottoman Empire. John Zápolya is recognized as King of Hungary (Eastern Hungarian Kingdom), while Ferdinand retains the northern and western parts of the Kingdom, and is recognized as heir to the throne.
March  – Garcia de Noronha is appointed as the new Governor-General of Portuguese India by King João III. He sails to Goa and arrives less than three weeks later.
End of Seventeenth Dynasty of Egypt, start of the Eighteenth Dynasty.
Approximate first use of the Valley of the Kings.
The oldest dated star chart was made in Ancient Egypt.
Joseph interprets dreams of the Pharaoh, is released from prison and becomes second in Egypt next only to the Pharaoh himself.
End of the First Dynasty of Babylon and the start of the Kassite Dynasty—see History of Iraq.
January  – Giannandrea Giustiniani Longo is elected to a two year term as Doge of the Republic of Genoa in Italy, succeeding Giovanni Battista Doria.

January  – Treaty of Toledo: Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor (and Charles I of Spain) and Francis I of France agree to make no further alliances with England. The treaty comes after Henry VIII of England's split with Rome and Pope Paul III.
January – Toungoo–Hanthawaddy War – Battle of Naungyo, Burma: The Toungoos decisively defeat the Hanthawaddys.
February  – The first horse race is held at Chester Racecourse, the oldest still in use in England.
March  – King Henry VIII of England summons Parliament to meet, with the session to start on April .
End of Seventeenth Dynasty of Egypt, start of the Eighteenth Dynasty.
Approximate first use of the Valley of the Kings.
The oldest dated star chart was made in Ancient Egypt.
Joseph interprets dreams of the Pharaoh, is released from prison and becomes second in Egypt next only to the Pharaoh himself.
End of the First Dynasty of Babylon and the start of the Kassite Dynasty—see History of Iraq.
January  – King Henry VIII marries Anne of Cleves, his fourth Queen consort; the marriage lasts six months.
February  – Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, enters Ghent without resistance, and executes rebels, ending the Revolt of Ghent (–).
March  – Waltham Abbey is the last to be closed as part of Henry VIII of England's  dissolution of the monasteries.
April – Estêvão da Gama becomes the new Governor of Portuguese India.
April – The English cathedral priories of Canterbury and Rochester are transformed into secular cathedral chapters on Easter Sunday, concluding the Dissolution of the Monasteries.
January  – Leonardo Cattaneo della Volta is elected to a two-year term as the new Doge of the Republic of Genoa, succeeding Giannandrea Giustiniani Longo

February  – (13th day of 1st month of Tenbun ) In Japan, the Siege of Yoshida-Kōriyama Castle, started by Amago Haruhisa of the , strong Amago clan the previous September in an attack against the Mōri clan led by Mōri Motonari and the Ōuchi clan, ends with a defeat of the attackers. The Amago clan sustains heavy losses, including the death of Amago Hisayuki.
February  – Pedro de Valdivia founds Santiago del Nuevo Extremo, which will become the capital of Chile.
February  – Petru Rareș becomes the Prince of Moldavia for a second time, overthrowing the Voivode Alexandru Cornea at Suceava (now in Romania) at the direction of the Ottoman Sultan Suleiman.

March  – At the Battle of Suakin, fought at an Ottoman port city on the Red Sea in what is now Sudan, Portuguese General Estêvão da Gama and his brother Cristóvão da Gama  lead an attack against the Ottoman ruler and plunder the city.
January  – In the Yucatan peninsula in Mexico, the Spanish colonists create the new town of Mérida.
January  – The 8th Parliament of Henry VIII assembles at Westminster after having been summoned on November .
January  – The first legislature for the Voivode of Transylvania meets at Vásárhely in the Kingdom of Hungary (now Târgu Mureș in Romania).

January  – Tutul-Xiu, the Mayan ruler of the Maní in Yucatán, arrives at the Spanish settlement of Merida with food supplies for the colonists and offers to assist the Spaniards in their conquest of Yucatan in return for being installed as the leading Mayan ruler in Mexico.
February  – Battle of Baçente: The Portuguese under Cristóvão da Gama capture a Muslim-occupied hillfort in northern Ethiopia.
January  – Andrea Centurione Pietrasanta begins a two-year term as the new Doge of the Republic of Genoa, replacing Leonardo Cattaneo della Volta.
January  – The burial of King James V of Scotland is carried out at Holyrood Abbey.
February  – King Henry VIII of England allies with Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, against France.

February  – Battle of Wayna Daga: A joint Ethiopian-Portuguese force of ,, under Emperor Gelawdewos of Ethiopia, defeats Imam Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi's army of over ,, ending the Ethiopian–Adal war.

March  –
Abu Abdallah Muhammad VI is installed as the new ruler of the Kingdom of Tlemcen in what is now Algeria, succeeding his brother Abu Zayyan III.
Massive flooding of the Mississippi River and the Arkansas River begins in southeastern North America over a  day period while Spanish explorer Hernando DeSoto and his team are passing through. The event is noted by the chronicler of the DeSoto Expedition, Inca Garcilaso de la Vega.

January  – In India, Maldeo Rathore, King of Marwar (now part of the state of Rajasthan) is tricked by counterintelligence spread by Mughal Emperor and Afghan Shah Sher Shah Suri into departing from Jodhpur. The Battle of Sammel begins shortly afterward and is won by the Afghan and Mughal armies.

January  – At Västerås, the estates of Sweden swear loyalty to King Gustav Vasa and to his heirs, ending the traditional electoral monarchy in Sweden. Gustav subsequently signs an alliance with the Kingdom of France.

January  – During a solar eclipse visible over the Netherlands, Dutch mathematician and designer Gemma Frisius makes the first recorded use of a camera obscura and uses it to observe the event without directly looking at the Sun. Frisius writes about the event the next year and illustrates it in his book De Radio Astronomica et Geometrica (Regarding rays of light in astronomy and geometry).
February  – The Fourth Diet of Speyer is convened.

March  – Five Roman Catholic priests— John Larke, John Ireland, the vicar of Eltham and Robert Singleton are executed at Tyburn, outside of London, in England after being convicted of participating in the Prebendaries' Plot to remove  Thomas Cranmer, the Protestant  Archbishop of Canterbury.
January  – King Francis I of France  issues the "Arrêt de Mérindol", to destroy the Protestant Waldensians of Provence.
January  – Giovanni Battista De Fornari begins a -year term as the Doge of Genoa, succeeding Andrea Centurione Pietrasanta.
February  – A firman of the Ottoman Empire is issued for the dethronement of Radu Paisie as Prince of Wallachia.
February  – Battle of Ancrum Moor: The Scots are victorious over numerically superior English forces.
March  – Mircea the Shepherd enters Bucharest as the new ruler of Wallachia, now in Romania.
January  – (Tenbun , 20th day of the 12th month):  Ashikaga Yoshifushi becomes 13th Shōgun of the Ashikaga shogunate.
January  – Jeremias I of Constantinople, Patriarch of the Eastern Orthodox Church dies
January  – Blasco Núñez Vela first Spanish Viceroy of Peru fights with Gonzalo Pizarro at the Battle of Iñaquito and is killed.
February  – The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mexico, one of the largest in the world, with over four million Catholics, is created
February  – Martin Luther delivers his final sermon, three days before his death about "obdurate Jews, whom it was a matter of great urgency to expel from all German territory,"
January  – The first Lithuanian-language book, a Catechism (Katekizmo paprasti žodžiai, Simple Words of Catechism), is published in Königsberg by Martynas Mažvydas.
January  – Henry Howard, Earl of Surrey is sentenced to death for treason in England.
January  – Grand Prince Ivan IV is crowned as Tsar of all Russia at the Dormition Cathedral in Moscow, thereby proclaiming the Tsardom of Russia.
January  – King Henry VIII of England dies in London, and is succeeded by his -year-old son Edward VI, as King of England.
February  – Edward VI of England is crowned at Westminster Abbey.

January  – Abu al-Abbas Ahmad III, ruler of the Hafsid Sultanate in what is now Tunisia in northern Africa, renews the  treaty of friendship with Spain that had been signed by representatives of his father.

January  – Three ships from the Portuguese Navy arrive at the port of Aden to assist Mohammed bin Ali al-Tawlaki, who has been defending the city against an attack by the Ottoman Navy. The Portuguese ships are forced to retreat to Zeila in Somalia, where  survivors are captured and their ships are burned.

January  – King Henri II of France makes the Châtillon agreement, a contract for betrothal for an arranged marriage between his four year old son, Prince Francois, to the five year old Mary, Queen of Scots, to take place in .

January  – (Tenbun , 30th day of 12th month) Nagao Kagetora (later Uesugi Kenshin) leads a triumphant entry into Kasugayama Castle in Japan, replacing his older brother Nagao Harukage as the lead samurai in the Nagao clan that rules the Echigo Province.

February  – On Candlemas day in Scotland, during the Rough Wooing War with England, the Byllye Castle near Auchencrow is captured by a force of  English soldiers led by Thomas Carlile, and becomes a garrison for English troops.
January  – Gaspare Grimaldi Bracelli begins a two-year term as the Doge of the Republic of Genoa in Italy, succeeding Benedetto Gentile Pevere.

January  – An uprising of the Diaguitas natives outside of the South American Spanish colonial city of La Serena (now in Coquimbo province of Chile) begins. Within a day, the South American village is burned down and nearly every Spanish resident is killed.
January  – Maha Chakkraphat is crowned as the King of Siam after having been installed on the throne in  by Maha Thammaracha of Burma.

January  – The Act of Uniformity  is passed by the Parliament of England and establishes the  version of the Book of Common Prayer as the sole legal prayer book in England, replacing the use of different versions of the Latin-language Missal.
January – Burmese–Siamese War (–): King Tabinshwehti of Burma begins his invasion of the Ayutthaya Kingdom, which ends in retreat.
January  – Spanish Captain Hernando de Santana founds the city of Valledupar, in modern-day Colombia.

February  – After a -week conclave in Rome to elect a new Pope, Giovanni Maria Ciocchi del Monte, Bishop of Palestrina, is selected on the 61st ballot after Reginald Pole of England falls two votes short of winning. Ciocchi del Monte takes the name Pope Julius III and is crowned the next day, succeeding the late Pope Paul III.

February  – (10th day of 2nd month of Tenbun ) In Oita, Ōita Prefecture, an attack within the Ōtomo clan of Japanese samurai takes place after clan leader Ōtomo Yoshikazu seeks to disinherit his oldest son and to make his third son, Ōtomo Shioichimaru, as his designated successor. Supporters of the oldest son, Ōtomo Yoshishige, invade Yoshikazu's home and kill Shioichimaru and four other family members.

March 
Arauco War: Battle of Penco – Several hundred Spanish and indigenous troops under the command of Pedro de Valdivia defeat an army of , Mapuche in modern-day Chile.
Acapulco is founded by  families sent from Mexico City.
Arauco War: Battle of Penco – Several hundred Spanish and indigenous troops under the command of Pedro de Valdivia defeat an army of , Mapuche in modern-day Chile.
The city of Mycenae, located in the northeast Peloponnesus, comes to dominate the rest of Achaea, giving its name to the Mycenaean civilization.
Estimation: Memphis, capital of Lower Egypt becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Avaris, capital of the Hyksos in Egypt.

Cecrops I builds or rebuilds Athens following the great flood of Deucalion and the end of the Silver age. He becomes the first of several Kings of Athens whose life account is considered part of Greek mythology.
c. —End of Second Intermediate period in Ancient Egypt. Start of New Kingdom. 18th–20th Dynasties.
c. —Second Intermediate Period ends in Ancient Egypt (other date is ).
January  – Luca Spinola is elected to a two-year term as the new Doge of the Republic of Genoa, succeeding Gaspare Grimaldi Bracelli.

January  (5th waxing of Tabodwe  ME) – King Bayinnaung of Burma is successful in capturing his ancestral city of Toungoo from his rebellious half-brother Minkhaung II, and sets about to make Toungoo the capital for the first time since . Minkhaung is forgiven by King Bayinnaung rather than being executed, and assists in the King's campaign to capture the neighboring Kingdom of Prome.

January– Macarius, Metropolitan of Moscow, and Tsar Ivan IV of Russia preside over the reforming Stoglavy Synod ("Hundred-Chapter") church council. A calendar of the saints and an ecclesiastical law code (Stoglav) are introduced.

February  – Alice Arden and her lover, Richard Mosbey, carry out the murder-for-hire of her husband, Thomas Arden of Faversham with the assistance of a highwayman known as "Black Will", two of Arden’s domestic servants (Michael Saunderson and Elizabeth Stafford) and Mosbye's sister (Cicely Pounder). The body is carried outside, and Thomas is reported as missing, but a discovery is made that the murder was committed inside the house. The conspirators are later executed.

February – At the Kremlin in Moscow,  Tsar Ivan IV and the Metropolitan Macarius, present the proposed code of laws, drafted by the Stoglavy Synod, to the clergy, nobility and principal Russian citizens for their approval.
The city of Mycenae, located in the northeast Peloponnesus, comes to dominate the rest of Achaea, giving its name to the Mycenaean civilization.
Estimation: Memphis, capital of Lower Egypt becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Avaris, capital of the Hyksos in Egypt.

Cecrops I builds or rebuilds Athens following the great flood of Deucalion and the end of the Silver age. He becomes the first of several Kings of Athens whose life account is considered part of Greek mythology.

c. —Second Intermediate Period ends in Ancient Egypt (other date is ).
January  – Henry II of France and Maurice, Elector of Saxony, sign the Treaty of Chambord.
February  – Pedro de Valdivia founds the Chilean city of Valdivia, as Santa María la Blanca de Valdivia.
February  – The privileges of the Hanseatic League are abolished in England.
March  – Guru Amar Das becomes the Third Sikh Guru.
April  – Maurice, Elector of Saxony, liberates Augsburg and sets about to capture Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor.
The city of Mycenae, located in the northeast Peloponnesus, comes to dominate the rest of Achaea, giving its name to the Mycenaean civilization.
Estimation: Memphis, capital of Lower Egypt becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Avaris, capital of the Hyksos in Egypt.

c. —Second Intermediate Period ends in Ancient Egypt (other date is ).

January  – The siege of Metz in France, started by Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor during the Italian War of – on October  last is lifted after  days. During the city's  defense by the Duke of Guise and , soldiers, Charles V had lost two-thirds of his original force  of at least , men.

February  – In India, Timmaraja Wodeyar II becomes the sixth maharaja of the Kingdom of Mysore (a vassal state of the Vijayanagara Empire), after the death of his father, the Maharaja Chamaraja Wodeyar III.

February  – Lieutenant General Luis Álvarez de Toledo y Osorio temporarily serves as the Spanish Viceroy of Naples (in modern-day Italy) upon the death of his father, Pedro Álvarez de Toledo. Luis steps down after Pedro Pacheco de Villena is appointed as the new Viceroy in June.

March  – The second (and last) session of the Parliament of England during the reign of King Edward VI is opened by the King at Westminster and lasts until March . Sir James Dyer serves during the session as Speaker of the House of Commons.
April  – Shimun VIII Yohannan Sulaqa, leader of the Chaldean Catholic Church in modern-day Iraq, is recognized by Pope Julius III as the Patriarch of Mosul.
The city of Mycenae, located in the northeast Peloponnesus, comes to dominate the rest of Achaea, giving its name to the Mycenaean civilization.
Estimation: Memphis, capital of Lower Egypt becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Avaris, capital of the Hyksos in Egypt.

c. —Second Intermediate Period ends in Ancient Egypt (other date is ).
January  – A great fire breaks out in Eindhoven, Netherlands.

January  (10th waxing of Tabodwe  ME) – Bayinnaung is crowned king of the Burmese Taungoo Dynasty at his new capital at Pegu, after a previous coronation on January , , and takes the regnal name of Thiri Thudhamma Yaza.
January  – Edward Courtenay, one of the four plotters of Wyatt's rebellion in England, is arrested and reveals that an attempt will be made to overthrow the English government.
January  – São Paulo, Brazil, is founded.

January  – Wyatt's rebellion begins in England at Maidstone as Sir Thomas Wyatt reads a proclamation that Queen Mary of England’s marriage to King Philip of Spain will "bring upon this realm most miserable servitude, and establish popish religion". Within two days, Wyatt has raised , soldiers to join his plan to overthrow Queen Mary.
The city of Mycenae, located in the northeast Peloponnesus, comes to dominate the rest of Achaea, giving its name to the Mycenaean civilization.
Estimation: Memphis, capital of Lower Egypt becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Avaris, capital of the Hyksos in Egypt.

c. —Second Intermediate Period ends in Ancient Egypt (other date is ).
January  – The Kingdom of Ava in Upper Burma falls.
February  – The Diet of Augsburg begins.

February  – John Rogers is burned at the stake at Smithfield, London, becoming the first of the  Protestant martyrs of the English Reformation to be killed during the five and one-half year reign of Queen Mary I of England. His death is followed within the week by that of Laurence Saunders on February  in Coventry, and Rowland Taylor, Rector of Hadleigh, Suffolk, and John Hooper, deposed Bishop of Gloucester on February .
February  – The Muscovy Company is chartered in England to trade with the Tsardom of Russia and Richard Chancellor negotiates with the Tsar.
March  – Valencia, Venezuela, is founded by Captain Alonso Díaz Moreno.
The city of Mycenae, located in the northeast Peloponnesus, comes to dominate the rest of Achaea, giving its name to the Mycenaean civilization.
Estimation: Memphis, capital of Lower Egypt becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Avaris, capital of the Hyksos in Egypt.

c. —Second Intermediate Period ends in Ancient Egypt (other date is ).
January  – In Japan, Saitō Yoshitatsu, the eldest son of Saitō Dōsan, arranges the murders of his two younger brothers, Magoshiro and Kiheiji, and forces his father to flee from the Sagiyama Castle.
January  – Charles V abdicates the thrones of the Spanish Empire (including his colonies in the New World) in favor of his son, Philip II, and retires to a monastery.
January  – The Shaanxi earthquake, the deadliest earthquake in history, occurs with its epicenter in Shaanxi province, China; , people may have been killed.

January  – In India, at the Sher Mandal in Delhi, the Mughal Emperor Humayun trips while descending the stairs from his library and strikes the side of his head against a stone step, sustaining a fatal injury. He never regains consciousness and dies seven days later.
February  – Truce of Vaucelles: Fighting temporarily ends between France and Spain.
The city of Mycenae, located in the northeast Peloponnesus, comes to dominate the rest of Achaea, giving its name to the Mycenaean civilization.

c. —Second Intermediate Period ends in Ancient Egypt (other date is ).
January  – Pietro Giovanni Chiavica Cibo becomes the new Doge of the Republic of Genoa for a term of  years as the term of the Doge Agostino Pinelli Ardimenti comes to an end.

January  – Italian War of –: Gaspard II de Coligny, the French governor of Picardy (in northern France), launches surprise attacks on Douai and Lens in the Spanish Netherlands and captures both cities for France.
January  – Sigismund II Augustus, King of Poland and Grand Duke of Lithuania, issues an edict against Protestants, at the urging of the Archbishop Mikołaj Dzierzgowski, Primate of Poland.

January  – Bayinnaung, King of Burma and head of the Toungoo dynasty, conquers two the Shan States, Möng Mit and Hsipaw in what is now northern Myanmar. The event is later commemorated with an inscription on the Shwezigon Pagoda Bell.
February  – Pope Paul IV creates the metropolitan archdiocese of Portuguese India (based in Goa) separating the Goan diocese from the ecclesiastical province of Lisbon.
The city of Mycenae, located in the northeast Peloponnesus, comes to dominate the rest of Achaea, giving its name to the Mycenaean civilization.
Estimation: Memphis, capital of Lower Egypt becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Avaris, capital of the Hyksos in Egypt.

Cecrops I builds or rebuilds Athens following the great flood of Deucalion and the end of the Silver age. He becomes the first of several Kings of Athens whose life account is considered part of Greek mythology.

c. —Second Intermediate Period ends in Ancient Egypt (other date is ).
January  – French troops, led by Francis, Duke of Guise, take Calais, the last continental possession of the Kingdom of England, in the Siege of Calais.
January  – The Livonian War begins.
February  – The University of Jena is founded in Thuringia, Germany.
February  – (16th day of 1st month of Eiroku ) Takeda Shingen becomes the shugo (military governor) of Shinano Province after his successful military campaign there.

February  – Arauco War: Pedro de Avendaño, with sixty men, captures Caupolicán (the Mapuche Gran Toqui), who is leading their first revolt against the Spanish Empire (near Antihuala), encamped with a small band of followers.
The city of Mycenae, located in the northeast Peloponnesus, comes to dominate the rest of Achaea, giving its name to the Mycenaean civilization.
Estimation: Memphis, capital of Lower Egypt becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Avaris, capital of the Hyksos in Egypt.

c. —End of Second Intermediate period in Ancient Egypt. Start of New Kingdom. 18th–20th Dynasties.
c. —Second Intermediate Period ends in Ancient Egypt (other date is ).
January  – Elizabeth I of England is crowned, in Westminster Abbey.
February  – Queen Elizabeth I of England establishes the Church of England, with the Act of Uniformity  and the Act of Supremacy .  The Oath of Supremacy is reinstated.
March  – Emperor Gelawdewos of Ethiopia, defending his lands against the invasion of Nur ibn Mujahid, Sultan of Harar, is killed in battle. His brother, Menas, succeeds him as king.

March  – The Westminster Conference  opens at Westminster Hall in London with nine leading Catholic churchmen, and nine Protestant reformers of the Church of England. The conference adjourns on April  for Easter and never reconvenes.

April  – Peace of Cateau Cambrésis: After two days of negotiations, France makes peace with England and Spain, ending the Italian War of –. France gives up most of its gains in Italy (including Savoy), retaining only Saluzzo, but keeps the three Lorraine bishoprics of Metz, Toul, and Verdun, and the formerly English town of Calais.
The city of Mycenae, located in the northeast Peloponnesus, comes to dominate the rest of Achaea, giving its name to the Mycenaean civilization.
Estimation: Memphis, capital of Lower Egypt becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Avaris, capital of the Hyksos in Egypt.

January  – In the Kingdom of Scotland, French troops commanded by Henri Cleutin and Captain Corbeyran de Cardaillac Sarlabous sail across the Firth of Forth from Leith, which they are occupying, and fight with the Lords of the Congregation at Pettycur Bay near Kinghorn.

February  – Treaty of Berwick: Terms are agreed upon with the Lords of the Congregation in Scotland, for forces of the Kingdom of England to enter Scotland, to expel French troops defending the Regency of Mary of Guise.
March  – A Spanish-led expedition, commanded by Juan de la Cerda, 4th Duke of Medinaceli, overruns the Tunisian island of Djerba.

March  – Leaders of the Amboise conspiracy, including Godefroy de Barry, seigneur de La Renaudie, make an unsuccessful attempt to storm the château of Amboise, where the young French king and queen are residing. La Renaudie is subsequently caught and executed, along with over , of his followers.
March – Bairam Khan, the Vakil or prime minister of India's Mughal Empire, is forced to retire by the Emperor Akbar.
January  – Paolo Battista Giudice Calvi is elected as the new Doge of the Republic of Genoa, but serves for only eight months before dying in September.

January 
The Ordinance of Orléans suspends the persecution of the Protestant Huguenots in Kingdom of France.
Mughal Empire General Bairam Khan is assassinated by an Afghan warrior, Mubarak Khan Lohani, while traveling through Gujarat in India.
The Ordinance of Orléans suspends the persecution of the Protestant Huguenots in Kingdom of France.
Mughal Empire General Bairam Khan is assassinated by an Afghan warrior, Mubarak Khan Lohani, while traveling through Gujarat in India.

February  – Queen Elizabeth of England summons the Ambassador from Spain, Álvaro de la Quadra, for a private audience to ask how the Spanish government would react if she were to marry Robert Dudley, 1st Earl of Leicester, who had recently lost his wife Amy Robsart in a questionable accident.

January  – Shane O'Neill of Tír Eoghain pleads his cause at the Palace of Whitehall in London, before Queen Elizabeth I of England, who recognises his status. He returns to Ireland on May , and resumes his rebellious activities by November.
January  – Huguenots are recognized under the Edict of Saint-Germain.

January 
The Council of Trent reconvenes, after a gap of  years.
Thomas Norton and Thomas Sackville's play Gorboduc is performed for the first time, before Queen Elizabeth I of England. It is the first known English tragedy, and the first English language play to employ blank verse.
The Council of Trent reconvenes, after a gap of  years.

Thomas Norton and Thomas Sackville's play Gorboduc is performed for the first time, before Queen Elizabeth I of England. It is the first known English tragedy, and the first English language play to employ blank verse.

January  (January ,  O.S., January ,  N.S.) – The convocation of bishops and clerics of the Church of England is opened at St Paul's Cathedral in London by the Dean of the Arches, Robert Weston to agree upon the wording of what will become the Thirty-nine Articles, with the assembly adopting all but three of the Forty-two Articles promulgated during the reign of King Edward VI in . The conference lasts for three months before agreeing upon the Articles to be submitted for further modification.
January  – In Italy, Instituto Bancario San Paolo di Torino, a constituent of the major financial group Sanpaolo IMI, is founded.
February  – Sarsa Dengel succeeds his father Menas as Emperor of Ethiopia at age .
February  – Francis, Duke of Guise, is assassinated while besieging Orléans by Jean de Poltrot.

March  – The Edict of Amboise is signed at the Château d'Amboise by Catherine de' Medici, acting as regent for her son Charles IX of France, having been negotiated between the Huguenot Louis, Prince of Condé, and Anne, duc de Montmorency, Constable of France. It accords some toleration to the Huguenots, especially to aristocrats. It officially ends the first phase of the French Wars of Religion, and the combined Huguenot and royal armies then march north to besiege the English in Le Havre.
January  – Livonian War – Battle of Ula: A Lithuanian surprise attack results in a decisive defeat of the numerically superior Russian forces.

February  (11th waning of Tabodwe  ME) – Burmese–Siamese War: Invaders from Burma overcome the seaside defenses of the Siamese capital at Ayutthava, capturing the batteries of cannons and a set of ships sent by Portugal to help defend the kingdom.

February  (8th waxing of Tabaung  ME) – The Burmese–Siamese War ends with the surrender of King Maha Chakkraphat of Ayutthaya (now Thailand) to King Bayinnaung of Burma). Chhakkraphat is allowed to go into exile and his son Mahinthrathirat is installed by Bayinnaung as the vassal king of Ayutthaya.
February  – Francisco Coutinho III, Count of Redondo and the Viceroy of Portuguese India, dies and is succeeded by João de Mendonça Furtado
February  – A group of four men assassinate the Spanish Viceroy of Peru, Diego López de Zúñiga, 4th Count of Nieva. López is succeeded temporarily by Hernando de Saavedra.
January  – In the Tsardom of Russia, Ivan the Terrible originates the oprichnina (repression of the boyars (aristocrats)).
January  – Battle of Talikota: The Vijayanagara Empire, the last Hindu kingdom in South India, is greatly weakened by the Deccan sultanates.
February  – Spanish Conquistador Miguel López de Legazpi lands with his troops on the shores of Cebu Island in the Philippines.
March  – The city of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, is founded as São Sebastião do Rio de Janeiro by Estácio de Sá.
March  – Spanish Conquistador López de Legazpi makes a blood compact (sandugan) with Datu Sikatuna in the island of Bohol, Philippines.

January  – Cardinal Michele Ghislieri is elected as the new Pope by two-thirds of the College of Cardinals, to succeed Pope Pius IV, who had died  days earlier on December . Ghislieri becomes the 225th pope, and takes the regnal name Pope Pius V.

February  – In one of the first gun assassinations in Japanese (if not world) history, Mimura Iechika, the daimyō (warlord) of the Bitchū Province, is shot dead by two brothers (Endo Matajiro and Yoshijiro), sent by his rival Ukita Naoie.
March  – The foundation stone of Valletta, which will become Malta's capital city, is laid by Jean Parisot de Valette, Grand Master of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta.
March – The Hanseatic city of Lübeck launches the galleon Adler von Lübeck, probably the largest ship in the world at this time.
April  – The Compromise of Nobles is presented to Margaret of Parma, Governor of the Habsburg Netherlands, but it succeeds only in delaying the beginning of the Eighty Years' War in the Netherlands.
January  – Battle of Rio de Janeiro: Portuguese forces under the command of Estácio de Sá definitively drive the French out of Rio de Janeiro.
January  – After  years' reign, the Jiajing Emperor, Zhu Houcong, dies in the Forbidden City of China.

January – A Spanish force under the command of Captain Juan Pardo establishes Fort San Juan, in the Native American settlement of Joara. The fort is the first European settlement in present-day North Carolina.
February  – Prince Zhu Zaiji, son of the Jiajing Emperor, ascends the throne of Ming Dynasty China as the Longqing Emperor.
February  – Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley, husband of Mary, Queen of Scots, is murdered at the Provost's House in Kirk o' Field, Edinburgh.
January  – In the Eastern Hungarian Kingdom, the delegates of Unio Trium Nationum to the Diet of Torda convene in a session that ends on January , during which freedom of religion is debated.
January  – The Edict of Torda, Europe's first declaration of religious freedom, is adopted by the Kingdom of Hungary.
February  – Members of a Spanish expedition, commanded by Álvaro de Mendaña de Neira, become the first Europeans to see the Solomon Islands, landing at Santa Isabel Island.
February  – Fernando Álvarez de Toledo, 3rd Duke of Alba, governor of the Spanish Netherlands issues an edict condemning to death those who rebel against Spanish authority to combat religious unrest.
February  – Treaty of Adrianople (sometimes called the Peace of Adrianople): The Habsburgs agree to pay tribute to the Ottomans.

January  — The first recorded lottery in England begins and continues, nonstop, at the west door of St Paul's Cathedral for almost five months. Each share costs ten shillings, and proceeds are used to repair harbours, and for other public works.
February  — Pope Pius V issues a papal bull expelling all Jews from Italian and French territories.

March  – Battle of Jarnac: Royalist troops under Marshal Gaspard de Tavannes surprise and defeat the Huguenots under the Prince of Condé, who is captured and murdered. A substantial proportion of the Huguenot army manages to escape, under Gaspard de Coligny.
April  – Burmese–Siamese War: In what is now Thailand, Mahinthrathirat reclaims the throne of the Ayutthaya Kingdom upon the death of King Maha Chakkraphat.
May  – England's St. Paul Cathedral lottery ends with the selection of a winner.
January  – Ivan the Terrible begins the Massacre of Novgorod.

January  – The assassination of Scottish regent James Stewart, 1st Earl of Moray, by James Hamilton, the first known shooting of a national leader, throws Scotland into civil war. Having loaded a carbine rifle and carried it into the Linlithgow home of his uncle, the Archbishop of St Andrews, Hamilton stands at an upstairs window overlooking the street where Moray will ride by on horseback as part of cavalcade. Once Moray comes into range, Hamilton fires and fatally wounds the regent for King James VI.
February  – An estimated . magnitude earthquake occurs in Concepción, Chile.
February  – Venus occults Jupiter; this will next happen in .

March  – The ambassador of the Ottoman Sultan Selim II goes before the governing Council of the Venetian Republic and requests that Venice surrender the island of Cyprus. The Council rejects the demand and prepares to go to war with the Ottoman Empire.
January  – The Austrian nobility are granted freedom of religion.
January  – The Royal Exchange opens in London, England.
February  – The Spanish Jesuit missionaries of the Ajacán Mission, established on the Virginia Peninsula of North America in , are massacred by local Native Americans.
March  – The Order of the Knights of Saint John transfers the capital of Malta, from Birgu to Valletta.

April 
The 3rd Parliament of Elizabeth I, with  members, assembles in England at Westminster after being summoned on February .
Dumbarton Castle is recaptured from Lord Fleming by the forces of Matthew Stewart, 4th Earl of Lennox, the Regent for King James VI of Scotland.
January  – Thomas Howard, 4th Duke of Norfolk, is tried for treason, for his part in the Ridolfi plot to restore Catholicism in England. He is executed on June .
February  – Elizabeth I of England issues a proclamation which revokes all commissions, on account of the frauds which they had fostered.
February  – Harrow School is founded, with a royal charter from Queen Elizabeth I of England.
February  – In what is now the Rajasthan state in India, Maharana Pratap is crowned as the new Rana of Mewar at the Kingdom's capital at Udaipur after the death of his father, Udai Singh II.
March  – Mem de Sá, the Portuguese Governor-General of Brazil, dies after  years in office. He is succeeded by Lourenço da Veiga.
January  (22nd day of 12th month of Genki  – At the Battle of Mikatagahara in Japan, Takeda Shingen defeats Tokugawa Ieyasu.

January 
Articles of the Warsaw Confederation are signed, sanctioning religious freedom in Poland.
The Croatian–Slovene Peasant Revolt, started by Matija Gubec,  breaks out against the Croatian nobility, but is suppressed after  days.
Articles of the Warsaw Confederation are signed, sanctioning religious freedom in Poland.
The Croatian–Slovene Peasant Revolt, started by Matija Gubec,  breaks out against the Croatian nobility, but is suppressed after  days.
February  – The Wanli Era begins in Ming dynasty China on the first New Year after -year-old Zhu Yijun ascends the throne.
January  – Mohammed II becomes the new Sultan of Morocco upon the death of his father, Abdallah al-Ghalib.
January  – At Agra, Bhagwant Das becomes the new Maharaja of the Kingdom of Amber in what is now India's state of Uttar Pradesh, upon the death of his grandfather, the Raja Bharmal.

January  – Off of the coast of the Netherlands, the Battle of the Scheldt is fought between the Spanish Fleet and a combined Dutch and English fleet of ships. The Spanish Navy loses  ships and , men are killed, wounded or captured.
February – The fifth War of Religion against the Huguenots begins in France.
March  – Swedish troops attack Wesenberg Castle in Estonia and lose at least , men in attempting to capture it from the Russian Army.
January  – Queen Elizabeth I of England grants a monopoly on producing printed sheet music, to Thomas Tallis and William Byrd.
February  – William I of Orange founds Leiden University.
February  – Portuguese explorer Paulo Dias de Novais arrives in southeastern Africa to colonize what is now Angola.

February  – The formal coronation of Henry III as King of France takes place at the Reims Cathedral. Henry inherited the throne on May , , upon the death of his older brother, Charles IX. He marries Louise de Lorraine-Vaudémont.
March  – Battle of Tukaroi: The Mughal Empire decisively defeats the Karrani dynasty of Bengal. The battle took place near the village of Tukaroi in present-day Balasore District of Odisha.
January  – Martín Enríquez de Almanza, Viceroy of New Spain, founds the settlement of León, in what is later the state of Guanajuato in Mexico.
January  – The establishment of Roman Catholic Diocese of Macau.
January  – Portuguese explorer Paulo Dias de Novais founds the settlement of São Paulo da Assumpção de Loanda on the southwestern coast of Africa, modern Luanda, capital of Angola.
February  – King Henry of Navarre, captive in France since  and alive only because he converted to Catholicism, escapes to Tours and formally reverts to the Protestant faith.

February  – Peter Wentworth, a Puritan M.P. of the Parliament of England, is arrested in the middle of giving an address criticizing "rumours and messages" given to suppress freedom of speech. When he says that "the devil was the first author of them, from whom proceedeth nothing but wickedness", he is interrupted and taken to the Tower of London for imprisonment.

January  – The second Union of Brussels is formed, first without the Protestant counties of Holland and Zeeland (which is accepted by King Philip II of Spain), later with the Protestants, which means open rebellion of the whole of the Netherlands.

February  – The "Perpetual Edict", providing for the removal of Spanish troops from what is now the Netherlands, is signed in the city of Marche-en-Famenne in the Spanish Netherlands (now Belgium) by the Spanish Governor-General, Don Juan de Austria and representatives of the Dutch rebellion. The Perpetual Edict will last only five months, before Don Juan begins new attacks on the rebels.
February  – The new Shah of Iran, Ismail II, has most of the advisers of his late father executed, including Prince Ibrahim Mirza.
March  – The Cathay Company is formed, to send Martin Frobisher back to the New World for more gold.

April  – Battle of Lubieszów: General Jan Zborowski leads the army of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth in the catastrophic defeat of most of Jan Winkelbruch's , rebels and mercenaries from the Commonwealth's richest city, Danzig, killing , of the men and capturing another , as prisoners. Only  of Zborowski's , troops are killed. The Danzig Rebellion ends at the end of the year.
January  – The Siege of Gvozdansko ends in the Kingdom of Croatia as Ottoman Empire troops led by Ferhad Pasha Sokolović capture the fortress at Gvozdansko.
January  – Battle of Gembloux: Spanish forces under Don John of Austria and Alexander Farnese defeat the Dutch; Farnese begins to recover control of the French-speaking Southern Netherlands.

February  – Pope Gregory XIII issues the papal bull Illius fulti praesidio and creates the Diocese of Manila, the first Roman Catholic diocese in the Philippines, with Domingo de Salazar as the first Bishop of Manila. The diocese will be raised to the status of archdiocese on August , .
February  – The city council of Amsterdam in the Netherlands ratifies a treaty placing the city under the authority of Willem, Prince of Orange, and joining the States of Holland.

February  – Mohammad Khodabanda, older brother of the late Shah Ismail II, begins his reign as the new Shah of Persia (now Iran) after entering the Persian capital at Qazvin, after removing his sister Pari Khan Khanum, who had exercised regal authority after Ismail's death. His first act as ruler is to have Pari Khan Khanum strangled to death.
January   – The Union of Arras unites the southern Netherlands under the Duke of Parma, governor in the name of king Philip II of Spain.

January  – The Union of Utrecht unites the northern Netherlands in a confederation called the United Provinces. William I of Orange becomes Stadtholder, and the Duc d'Anjou, younger brother of Henry III of France, is invited to become hereditary sovereign.
February  – The Ghent Republic joins the Union of Utrecht.
February  – The seizure in September by Willem IV van den Bergh, of the Boxmeer Castle in September in the Netherlands is condemned by the other Dutch members of the Union of Utrecht.

March  – Off of the coast of what is now Ecuador, the English galleon Golden Hind, captained by Francis Drake, captures the Spanish freighter Nuestra Señora de la Concepción (unofficially called "Cagafuego") and its cargo, including  tons of silver and , pounds of gold.

January  – Portuguese succession crisis of : The death of Henry, King of Portugal, with no direct heirs, leads to conflict between his potential successors, including King Philip II of Spain and Infanta Catherine, Duchess of Braganza.
February  – The massacre of  artists at the Mardi Gras festivities, at the annual Carnaval de Romans during the festival, takes place in France at Romans-sur-Isère.

February  – Three Jesuit priests from Portuguese Goa, including Rodolfo Acquaviva, arrive in Agra on the mainland of India as guests of the Mughal Emperor, Akbar the Great, who is curious about Christianity. The Emperor grants land to the Jesuit fathers for the building of the first Roman Catholic Church in the Mughal Empire.
March  – Michel de Montaigne signs the preface to his most significant work, Essays. They are published later this year.
March  – George de Lalaing, Count of Rennenberg defects from the Union of Utrecht and the Dutch Republic, and turns over the province of Groningen to King Philip II of Spain.

January  – Chandrasen Rathore, ruler of the Kingdom of Marwar (now part of the state of Rajasthan in India) dies at the age of , leaving a power vacuum that allows the Mughal Empire to take control of the kingdom.
January  – The Treaty of Drohiczyn is concluded, ending the Livonian War and adding the conquered city of Riga to the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.

January  – The Treaty of Plessis-les-Tours between the Duchy of Anjou and most of the states of the Dutch Republic is ratified at Bourdeaux, granting François, Duke of Anjou executive authority over the Republic with the title "Protector of the Liberty of the Netherlands".

February  – (7th waxing of Tabaung  ME) Prince Shin Thissa, later to become King of Burma in  as Nyaungyan Min, receives his first executive job when he is appointed to be Governor of Nyaungyan by his father, King Bayinnaung.
February  – The Spanish Army is forced to abandon the siege of Steenwijk in the Netherlands after more than four months.
January  – The University of Würzburg is refounded.
January  – Russia cedes its conquered areas in Livonia (Northern Latvia and Southern Estonia), to the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
February  – François, Duke of Anjou, arrives in the Netherlands, where he is personally welcomed by William the Silent.

February  (Julian) (March  Gregorian) – Pope Gregory XIII proclaims the Gregorian calendar, to come into effect in October. Under the order, the date on the Julian calendar will be advanced by  days in order to synchronize the calendar date back to the equinoxes and solstices, since the gap has been increasing by one day every  years since the  and is  days off schedule.
March  – Scryer Edward Kelley arrives at John Dee's house in London. They practice angelic magic together and Dee develops the Enochian language.
January  – The Duchy of Savoy adopts the Gregorian Calendar, replacing the Julian Calendar.
January  – François, Duke of Anjou, attacks Antwerp.

February  – Gebhard Truchsess von Waldburg, newly converted to Calvinism, formally marries Agnes von Mansfeld-Eisleben, a former canoness of Gerresheim, while retaining his position as Archbishop-Elector of Cologne.
February  – In the Netherlands, the Siege of Eindhoven by the Spanish Army begins. The walled city will fall in April.
March  (February  O.S.) – The Queen Elizabeth's Men troupe of actors is founded in England by order of Queen Elizabeth to Edmund Tilney, the royal Master of the Revels.
January  – Sir Walter Mildmay is given a royal licence to found Emmanuel College, Cambridge in England.
