January  – The North Carolina General Assembly authorizes nine commissioners to purchase  acres (. km) of land for the seat of Chatham County. The town is named Pittsborough (later shortened to Pittsboro), for William Pitt the Younger.
January  – William Herschel discovers Titania and Oberon, two moons of Uranus.
January  – Mozart's Symphony No.  is premièred in Prague.
February  – Arthur St. Clair of Pennsylvania is chosen as the new President of the Congress of the Confederation.
February  – Shays' Rebellion in Massachusetts fails.
c.  - The last known population of woolly mammoths on Wrangel Island died out, possibly due to a combination of climate change and hunting.
The Amorite civilization conquers Uruk and Isin.
In Egypt, the Twelfth Dynasty ends, and the Thirteenth and Fourteenth Dynasties begin.
January  – The first edition of The Times, previously The Daily Universal Register, is published in London.
January  – Georgia ratifies the United States Constitution, and becomes the fourth U.S. state under the new government.
January  – Connecticut ratifies the United States Constitution, and becomes the fifth U.S. state.
January  – The leading ship (armed tender HMS Supply) in Captain Arthur Phillip's First Fleet arrives at Botany Bay, to colonise Australia.

January  – The Congress of the Confederation, effectively a caretaker government until the United States Constitution can be ratified by at least nine of the  states, elects Cyrus Griffin as its last president.
c.  - The last known population of woolly mammoths on Wrangel Island died out, possibly due to a combination of climate change and hunting.
The Amorite civilization conquers Uruk and Isin.
In Egypt, the Twelfth Dynasty ends, and the Thirteenth and Fourteenth Dynasties begin.
January – Emmanuel Joseph Sieyès publishes the pamphlet What Is the Third Estate? (Qu'est-ce que le tiers-état?), influential on the French Revolution.
January  – The - United States presidential election and House of Representatives elections are held.

January  – Treaty of Fort Harmar: The terms of the Treaty of Fort Stanwix () and the Treaty of Fort McIntosh, between the United States Government and certain native American tribes, are reaffirmed, with some minor changes.
January  – The first American novel, The Power of Sympathy or the Triumph of Nature Founded in Truth, is printed in Boston, Massachusetts. The anonymous author is William Hill Brown.
January  – Georgetown University is founded in Georgetown, Maryland (part of modern-day Washington, D.C.), as the first Roman Catholic college in the United States.
c.  - The last known population of woolly mammoths on Wrangel Island died out, possibly due to a combination of climate change and hunting.
The Amorite civilization conquers Uruk and Isin.
In Egypt, the Twelfth Dynasty ends, and the Thirteenth and Fourteenth Dynasties begin.
January  – United States President George Washington gives the first State of the Union address, in New York City.
January  – The  minor states of the Austrian Netherlands, which took part in the Brabant Revolution at the end of , sign a Treaty of Union, creating the United States of Belgium.

January  – U.S. Secretary of the Treasury Alexander Hamilton submits his proposed plan for payment of American debts, starting with $,, to pay the foreign debts of the confederation, followed by $ million for domestic debts, and $. million for the war debts of the states. The plan is narrowly approved - in the Senate, and - in the House.
January  – Fletcher Christian &  mutineers aboard the Bounty land on Pitcairn.
January  – Mozart's opera Così fan tutte premieres in Vienna.
January  – Austrian composer Joseph Haydn arrives in England, to perform a series of concerts.
January  – Northwest Indian War: Big Bottom Massacre – The war begins in the Ohio Country, with this massacre.
January  – Holy Roman troops reenter Liège, heralding the end of the Liège Revolution, and the restoration of its Prince-Bishops.
January  – The British Parliament passes the Constitutional Act , splitting the old province of Quebec into Upper and Lower Canada.
February  – The Bank of the United States, based in Philadelphia, is incorporated by the federal government with a -year charter and started with $,, capital.
January  – The Treaty of Jassy ends the Russian Empire's war with the Ottoman Empire over Crimea.
January  – The London Corresponding Society is founded.
February  – Thomas Holcroft produces the comedy The Road to Ruin in London.

February 
The Postal Service Act, establishing the United States Post Office Department, is signed by President George Washington.
Parliament House, Dublin catches fire during a legislative session. "Although in imminent danger of the roof falling in," it is noted later, "the House did not adjourn until a proper motion had been put and carried in the affirmative."
The Postal Service Act, establishing the United States Post Office Department, is signed by President George Washington.
January  – The Ebel riot occurs in Sweden.
January  – Jean-Pierre Blanchard becomes the first to fly in a gas balloon in the United States.
January  – Nicolas Jean Hugon de Bassville, a representative of Revolutionary France, is lynched by a mob in Rome.
January  – French Revolution: After being found guilty of treason by the French National Convention, Citizen Capet, formerly King Louis XVI, is guillotined in Paris.Second Partition of Poland in
January  – Second Partition of Poland: The Russian Empire and the Kingdom of Prussia partition the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
January  – The Stibo Group is founded by Niels Lund as a printing company in Aarhus (Denmark).

January  – The U.S. Congress enacts a law providing for, effective May , , a United States flag of  stars and  stripes, in recognition of the recent admission of Vermont and Kentucky as the 14th and 15th states. A subsequent act restores the number of stripes to , but provides for additional stars upon the admission of each additional state.
January  – King George III of Great Britain delivers the speech opening Parliament and recommends a continuation of Britain's war with France.
February  – French Revolution: The National Convention of the French First Republic abolishes slavery.
February  – Wreck of the Ten Sail on Grand Cayman.
January – Central England records its coldest ever month, in the CET records dating back to .
January  – The University of North Carolina opens to students at Chapel Hill, becoming the first state university in the United States.
January  – War of the First Coalition: Flanders campaign: The French occupy Utrecht, Netherlands.
January  – Batavian Revolution in Amsterdam: William V, Prince of Orange, Stadtholder of the Dutch Republic (Republic of the Seven United Netherlands), flees the country.
January  – The Batavian Republic is proclaimed in Amsterdam, ending the Dutch Republic (Republic of the Seven United Netherlands).
January  – The first Dutch (and general) elections are held for the National Assembly of the Batavian Republic. (The next Dutch general elections are held in .)
February  – The capital of Upper Canada is moved from Newark to York.
February  – The Qianlong Emperor of China abdicates at age  to make way for his son, the Jiaqing Emperor.
February  – French Revolutionary Wars: The Invasion of Ceylon () ends when Johan van Angelbeek, the Batavian governor of Ceylon, surrenders Colombo peacefully to British forces.
February  – The Kingdom of Great Britain is granted control of Ceylon by the Dutch.
January  – The Treaty of Tripoli, a peace treaty between the United States and Ottoman Tripolitania, is signed at Algiers (see also ).
January  – The parliament of the Cisalpine Republic adopts the Italian green-white-red tricolour as their official flag (this is considered the birth of the flag of Italy).

January  – Action of  January , part of the War of the First Coalition: Two British Royal Navy frigates, HMS Indefatigable and HMS Amazon, drive the French -gun ship of the line Droits de l'Homme aground on the coast of Brittany, resulting in over  deaths.

January  – War of the First Coalition – Battle of Rivoli: French forces under General Napoleon Bonaparte defeat an Austrian army of , men, under Feldzeugmeister József Alvinczi, near Rivoli (modern-day Italy), ending Austria's fourth and final attempt to relieve the fortress city of Mantua.
January  – The Treaty of the Third Partition of Poland is signed in St. Petersburg by the Russian Empire, Austria and the Kingdom of Prussia.
January – Eli Whitney contracts with the U.S. federal government for , muskets, which he produces with interchangeable parts.
January  – Constantine Hangerli enters Bucharest, as Prince of Wallachia.
January  – A coup d'état is staged in the Netherlands (Batavian Republic). Unitarian Democrat Pieter Vreede  ends the power of the parliament (with a conservative-moderate majority).
February  – The Pope is taken captive, and the Papacy is removed from power, by French General Louis-Alexandre Berthier.

February  – U.S. Representative Roger Griswold (Fed-CT) beats Congressman Matthew Lyon (Dem-Rep-VT) with a cane, after the House declines to censure Lyon for earlier spitting in Griswold's face; the House declines to discipline either man.
January  – British Prime Minister William Pitt the Younger introduces an income tax of two shillings to the pound, to raise funds for Great Britain's effort in the French Revolutionary Wars.
January  – Maltese patriot Dun Mikiel Xerri, along with a number of other patriots, is executed.
January  – The Parthenopean Republic is established in Naples by French General Jean Étienne Championnet; King Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies flees.
January  – French Revolutionary Wars: Macau Incident – French and Spanish warships encounter a British Royal Navy escort squadron in the Wanshan Archipelago of China inconclusively.

February  – The Jiaqing Emperor of China comes into his full powers on the death of his father, the Qianlong Emperor. He prosecutes corrupt court official Heshen and issues a decree prohibiting the import of opium to China.

January 
Quasi-War: Action of  January  – A naval battle off the coast of Haiti, between four United States merchant vessels escorted by naval schooner USS Experiment, and a squadron of armed barges manned by Haitian pirates (known as picaroons), under the command of general André Rigaud, ends indecisively.
The Dutch East India Company dissolves.

Quasi-War: Action of  January  – A naval battle off the coast of Haiti, between four United States merchant vessels escorted by naval schooner USS Experiment, and a squadron of armed barges manned by Haitian pirates (known as picaroons), under the command of general André Rigaud, ends indecisively.
The Dutch East India Company dissolves.
February  – A public plebiscite in France confirms Napoleon as First Consul, by a substantial majority.
February  – Infrared radiation is discovered by astronomer Sir William Herschel.

January 
The legislative union of Great Britain and Ireland is completed under the Act of Union , bringing about the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, and the abolition of the Parliament of Ireland.
Giuseppe Piazzi discovers the asteroid and dwarf planet Ceres.

The legislative union of Great Britain and Ireland is completed under the Act of Union , bringing about the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, and the abolition of the Parliament of Ireland.
Giuseppe Piazzi discovers the asteroid and dwarf planet Ceres.
January  – Toussaint Louverture triumphantly enters Santo Domingo, the capital of the former Spanish colony of Santo Domingo, which has become a colony of Napoleonic France.
January  – John Marshall is appointed Chief Justice of the United States.

January  – Thomas Bruce, 7th Earl of Elgin, British ambassador to the Ottoman Empire, begins removal of the Elgin Marbles from the Parthenon in Athens, claiming they are at risk of destruction during the Ottoman occupation of Greece; the first shipment departs Piraeus on board Elgin's ship, the Mentor, "with many boxes of moulds and sculptures", including three marble torsos from the Parthenon.
January  – Canonsburg Academy (modern-day Washington & Jefferson College) is chartered by the Pennsylvania General Assembly.

January  – The French Saint-Domingue expedition (, troops) led by General Charles Leclerc (Bonaparte's brother-in-law) lands in Saint-Domingue (modern Haiti) in an attempt to restore colonial rule following the Haitian Revolution in which Toussaint Louverture (a black former slave) has proclaimed himself Governor-General for Life and established control over Hispaniola.
February  – Leclerc and the first , of , troops arrive at Cap-François (modern Cap-Haïtien).
February  – The remains of Pope Pius VI are returned to the Vatican by France; the Pope had died in captivity at Valence, on August , .
January  – The first edition of Alexandre Balthazar Laurent Grimod de La Reynière's Almanach des gourmands, the first guide to restaurant cooking, is published in Paris.
January  – William Symington demonstrates his Charlotte Dundas, the "first practical steamboat", in Scotland.
January  – Monroe and Livingston sail for Paris to discuss, and possibly buy, New Orleans; they end up completing the Louisiana Purchase.

February 
An Act of Mediation, issued by Napoleon Bonaparte, establishes the Swiss Confederation to replace the Helvetic Republic. Under the terms of the act, Graubünden, St. Gallen, Thurgau, the Ticino and Vaud become Swiss cantons.
Ohio is admitted as the 17th U.S. state.

An Act of Mediation, issued by Napoleon Bonaparte, establishes the Swiss Confederation to replace the Helvetic Republic. Under the terms of the act, Graubünden, St. Gallen, Thurgau, the Ticino and Vaud become Swiss cantons.
January  – Haiti gains independence from France, becoming the first independent Black state in the New World.
February  – The Sokoto Caliphate is founded in West Africa.

February  – The First Serbian uprising begins the Serbian Revolution. By , the Principality of Serbia will have proclaimed self-rule from the Ottoman Empire, the first nation-state in Europe to do so.
February  – New Jersey becomes the last of the northern United States to abolish slavery.
February  – First Barbary War: Stephen Decatur leads a raid to burn the pirate-held frigate USS Philadelphia at Tripoli to deny her further use by the captors.
January  – The Michigan Territory is created.
February  – King Anouvong becomes ruler of Vientiane on the death of his brother Inthavong.
February  – The Harmony Society is officially formed as a Christian community in Harmony, Pennsylvania.
March  – Justice Samuel Chase is acquitted of impeachment charges by the United States Senate.
March  –  The New Brunswick Legislature passes a bill to advance literacy in the province, which eventually leads to the creation of public education in Canada.

January 
The French Republican Calendar is abolished.
The Kingdom of Bavaria is established by Napoleon.
The French Republican Calendar is abolished.
The Kingdom of Bavaria is established by Napoleon.
January  – The body of British naval leader Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson, lies in state in the Painted Hall of Greenwich Hospital, London, prior to his funeral.
January  – Battle of Blaauwberg: British infantry force troops of the Batavian Republic in the Dutch Cape Colony to withdraw.
January  – The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland issues an Order in Council prohibiting British ships from trading with France or its allies.

January  – The Sierra Leone Company, faced with bankruptcy because of the imminent abolition of the slave trade in British colonies, petitions the British government for purchase and transfer of its property to the Crown; Parliament approves the transfer on July , and it takes effect on January , .
February  – Napoleonic Wars and Anglo-Spanish War: Battle of Montevideo – The British Army captures Montevideo from the Spanish Empire, as part of the British invasions of the Río de la Plata.
February  – Napoleon leads the forces of the French Empire in an invasion of the Russian Empire, and begins fighting at the Battle of Eylau against Russian and Prussian forces.
February  – Battle of Eylau: Napoleon fights a hard but inconclusive battle against the Russians under Bennigsen.

January 
The importation of slaves into the United States is formally banned, as the  Act Prohibiting Importation of Slaves takes effect. However Americans still continue the slave trade by transporting Africans to Cuba and Brazil.
Sierra Leone becomes a British Crown Colony.

The importation of slaves into the United States is formally banned, as the  Act Prohibiting Importation of Slaves takes effect. However Americans still continue the slave trade by transporting Africans to Cuba and Brazil.
Sierra Leone becomes a British Crown Colony.

January  – Transfer of the Portuguese court to Brazil: John (Dom João), Prince Regent, and the Braganza royal family of Portugal arrive in their colony of Brazil in exile from the French occupation of their home kingdom.

January  – Rum Rebellion: On the 20th anniversary of the foundation of the colony of New South Wales, disgruntled military officers of the New South Wales Corps (the "Rum Corps") overthrow and imprison Governor William Bligh and seize control of the colony.
January  – The Treaty of the Dardanelles, between the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and the Ottoman Empire, is concluded.
January  – Peninsular War – French Marshal Jean Lannes begins the Siege of Zaragoza.
January  – The Apodaca–Canning treaty is signed in London between Britain and Spain

January  –  Peninsular War – Battle of Corunna in Galicia (Spain): The  British (under General Sir John Moore, who is killed) resist an attempt by the French (under Marshal Soult) to prevent them embarking.
February  – The Illinois Territory is created from the western part of the Indiana Territory.
January  – Major-General Lachlan Macquarie officially becomes Governor of New South Wales.
January  – Australian seal hunter Frederick Hasselborough discovers Campbell Island, in the Subantarctic.
January  – The marriage of Napoleon and Joséphine is annulled.
February  – After seizing Jaén, Córdoba, Seville and Granada, Napoleonic troops enter Málaga under the command of General Horace Sebastiani.
February  – Napoleon Bonaparte decrees that Rome would become the second capital of the French Empire.
January  – An unsuccessful slave revolt is led by Charles Deslondes, in St. Charles and St. James Parishes, Louisiana.
January  – Mexican War of Independence – Battle of Calderón Bridge: A heavily outnumbered Spanish force of , troops defeats nearly , Mexican revolutionaries.
January  – The Casas Revolt begins in San Antonio, Spanish Texas.
February  – British Regency: George, Prince of Wales becomes prince regent, because of the perceived insanity of his father, King George III of the United Kingdom.
February  – Peninsular War – Battle of the Gebora: An outnumbered French force under Édouard Mortier routs and nearly destroys the Spanish, near Badajoz, Spain.
January  – The Allgemeines bürgerliches Gesetzbuch (the Austrian civil code) enters into force in the Austrian Empire.
January  – Peninsular War: The French-held fortress of Ciudad Rodrigo is stormed by the Anglo-Portuguese Army, under the Earl of Wellington.
February  – The last New Madrid earthquake strikes New Madrid, Missouri, with an estimated moment magnitude of over .
February  – Napoleon authorizes the usage of Mesures usuelles, the basis of the metric system.
February  – The first Chilean newspaper Aurora de Chile deals with political philosophy, and stands in favor of the new national government.
January  – The Danish state bankruptcy of  occurs.
January – – War of : The Battle of Frenchtown is fought in modern-day Monroe, Michigan between the United States and a British and Native American alliance.
January  – The Philharmonic Society (later the Royal Philharmonic Society) is founded in London.
January  – Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice is published anonymously in London.
January  – The Assembly of the Year XIII is inaugurated in Buenos Aires.
January  – War of the Sixth Coalition – The Royal Prussian Army led by Gebhard Leberecht von Blücher crosses the Rhine.

January 
War of the Sixth Coalition – Siege of Cattaro: French garrison surrenders to the British after ten days of bombardment.
War of the Sixth Coalition – Siege of Metz: Allied armies lay siege to the French city and fortress of Metz.
War of the Sixth Coalition – Siege of Cattaro: French garrison surrenders to the British after ten days of bombardment.
War of the Sixth Coalition – Siege of Metz: Allied armies lay siege to the French city and fortress of Metz.
January  – Mexican War of Independence –  Battle of Puruarán: Spanish Royalists defeat Mexican Rebels.
January  – Lord Byron marries Anna Isabella Milbanke in Seaham, county of Durham, England.
January  – Austria, Britain, and Bourbon-restored France form a secret defensive alliance treaty against Prussia and Russia.

January  – Battle of New Orleans: American forces led by Andrew Jackson defeat British forces led by Sir Edward Pakenham. American forces suffer around  casualties and the British lose about , (the battle lasts for about  minutes).
January  – War of : British troops capture Fort Peter in St. Marys, Georgia, the only battle of the war to take place in the state.
January  – War of : Capture of USS President – American frigate USS President (), commanded by Commodore Stephen Decatur, is captured by a squadron of four British frigates.
January  – (December ,  on the Russian Julian calendar): Tsar Alexander I of Russia signs an order, expelling the Jesuits from St. Petersburg and Moscow.
Sir Humphry Davy's Davy lamp is first tested underground as a coal mining safety lamp, at Hebburn Colliery in northeast England;
Ludwig van Beethoven wins the custody battle for his nephew Karl.
January  – Fire nearly destroys the city of St. John's, Newfoundland.
January  – Sailing through the Sandwich Islands, Otto von Kotzebue discovers New Year Island.
January  – An army of , soldiers, led by General José de San Martín, starts crossing the Andes from Argentina, to liberate Chile and then Peru.
January  – Ram Mohan Roy and David Hare found Hindu College, Calcutta, offering instructions in English on Western subjects, including other European languages.

February  – Battle of Chacabuco: Argentine and Chilean soldiers of the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata defeat the Spanish royalist troops in what is now Chile, marking the turning point in the war against European rule of South America.

March 
On his last day in office, U.S. President James Madison vetoes John C. Calhoun's Bonus Bill as unconstitutional after it has passed both houses of the U.S. Congress.
The U.S. Congress passes a law to split the Mississippi Territory, after Mississippi drafts a constitution, creating the Alabama Territory, effective in August.

January 
Battle of Koregaon: Troops of the British East India Company score a decisive victory over the Maratha Empire.
English author Mary Shelley publishes the novel Frankenstein anonymously.
Battle of Koregaon: Troops of the British East India Company score a decisive victory over the Maratha Empire.
English author Mary Shelley publishes the novel Frankenstein anonymously.
January  (: UTC) – Venus occults Jupiter. It is the last occultation of one planet by another before November , .

January  – The Treaty of Mandeswar brings an end to the Third Anglo-Maratha War, ending the dominance of Marathas, and enhancing the power of the British East India Company, which controls territory occupied by  million Indians.
January  – The Panic of , the first major peacetime financial crisis in the United States, begins.
January  – Thomas Jefferson founds the University of Virginia.
January  – Sir Stamford Raffles lands on the island of Singapore.

February  – Dartmouth College v. Woodward: The Supreme Court of the United States under John Marshall rules in favor of Dartmouth College, allowing Dartmouth to keep its charter and remain a private institution.
February  – The Treaty of Singapore, is signed between Hussein Shah of Johor and Sir Stamford Raffles of Britain, to create a trading settlement in Singapore.[]
January  – A constitutionalist military insurrection at Cádiz leads to the summoning of the Spanish Parliament to meet on March , becoming the nominal beginning of the "Trienio Liberal" in Spain.

January  – The General Maritime Treaty of  is signed between the sheikhs of Abu Dhabi, Sharjah, Ajman, Umm al-Quwain and Ras Al Khaimah (later constituents of the Trucial States) in the Arabian Peninsula and the United Kingdom.
January  (NS, January  OS) – An Imperial Russian Navy expedition, led by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen in Vostok with Mikhail Petrovich Lazarev, sights the Antarctic ice sheet.

January  – George IV of the United Kingdom becomes the new British monarch upon the death his father King George III after  years on the throne. The elder George's death ends the -year period known as the British Regency.
January  – British Royal Navy captain Edward Bransfield, an Irishman,  becomes the first person to positively identify Antarctica as a land mass.
January  – Peter I Island in the Antarctic is first sighted, by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen.
January  – Congress of Laibach convenes to deal with outstanding international issues, particularly the outbreak of a revolution in southern Italy.
January  – Alexander Island, the largest in Antarctica, is first discovered by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen.
February  – Columbian College in the District of Columbia is chartered by President James Monroe (it becomes George Washington University).
February  – In Mexico, the Embrace of Acatempan takes place between Agustín de Iturbide and Vicente Guerrero, which seals the peace between the viceroyalty troops and the insurgents.
January  – The Greek Constitution of  is adopted by the First National Assembly at Epidaurus.
January  – The famous French explorer, Aimé Bonpland, is imprisoned in Paraguay on charges of espionage.
January  – The first freed slaves from the United States arrive on the west coast of Africa, founding Monrovia on April .
January  – The Portuguese prince Pedro I of Brazil decides to stay in Brazil against the orders of the Portugal's King João VI, beginning the Brazilian independence process.
January  – The design of the modern-day flag of Greece is adopted by the First National Assembly at Epidaurus, for their naval flag.

January  – By secret treaty signed at the Congress of Verona, the Quintuple Alliance gives France a mandate to invade Spain for the purpose of restoring Ferdinand VII (who has been captured by armed revolutionary liberals) as absolute monarch of the country.

January  – In Paviland Cave on the Gower Peninsula of Wales, William Buckland inspects the "Red Lady of Paviland", the first identification of a prehistoric (male) human burial (although Buckland dates it as Roman).

February 
Jackson Male Academy, precursor of Union University, opens in Alabama.
Gioachino Rossini's opera Semiramide is first performed, at La Fenice in Venice.
Jackson Male Academy, precursor of Union University, opens in Alabama.
Gioachino Rossini's opera Semiramide is first performed, at La Fenice in Venice.
January  – After much controversy, Michael Faraday is finally elected as a member of the Royal Society in London, with only one vote against him.
January  – First Anglo-Ashanti War: Battle of Nsamankow – forces of the Ashanti Empire crush British forces in the Gold Coast (modern-day Ghana), killing the British governor Sir Charles MacCarthy.
February  – Simón Bolívar is proclaimed dictator of Peru.
February  — William Buckland formally announces the name Megalosaurus, the first scientifically validly named non-avian dinosaur species.

February  – The Chumash Revolt of  begins against the Spanish presence in Alta California (now the U.S. state of California) as an uprising by the Chumash people at Mission Santa Inés (now Solvang, Mission Santa Barbara, and Mission La Purisima (now Lompoc in what is now Santa Barbara County, California. By June , the uprising ends after the Spanish government and the Chumash leaders reach a peace agreement.
January  – King Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies dies in Naples and is succeeded by his son, Francis.
February  – Vendsyssel-Thy, once part of the Jutland peninsula forming westernmost Denmark, becomes an island after a flood drowns its  kilometre (. mi) wide isthmus.

February  – After no presidential candidate receives a majority of United States Electoral College votes following the  United States presidential election, the United States House of Representatives elects John Quincy Adams President of the United States in a contingent election.
February  – Gideon Mantell names and describes the second known dinosaur Iguanodon.
February  – Simón Bolívar gives up his title of dictator of Peru and takes the alternative title of El Libertador.
January  – The French newspaper Le Figaro begins publication in Paris, initially as a satirical weekly.

January  – The Ballantyne printing business in Edinburgh (Scotland) crashes, ruining novelist Sir Walter Scott as a principal investor. He undertakes to repay his creditors from his writings. His publisher, Archibald Constable, also fails.
January  – In India, the Siege of Bharatpur ends in British victory as Lord Combermere and Michael Childers defeat the princely state of Bharatpur, part of the modern-day Indian state of Rajasthan.
January  – The Menai Suspension Bridge, built by engineer Thomas Telford as the first major suspension bridge in world history, is opened between the island of Anglesey and the mainland of Wales.
February  –  James Fenimore Cooper's novel The Last of the Mohicans is first printed, by a publisher in Philadelphia.
January  – The first regatta in Australia is held, taking place in Tasmania (called at the time Van Diemen's Land), on the River Derwent at Hobart.

January  – Furman University, founded in , begins its first classes with  students, as the Furman Academy and Theological Institution, located in Edgefield, South Carolina. By the end of , it will have , students at its main campus in Greenville, South Carolina.

January  – Author Johann Wolfgang von Goethe first elaborates on his vision of Weltliteratur (world literature), in a letter to Johann Peter Eckermann, declaring his belief that "poetry is the universal possession of mankind", and that "the epoch of world literature is at hand, and each must work to hasten its coming."
January  – The first public theatre in Norway, the Christiania Offentlige Theater, is inaugurated in Christiania (modern-day Oslo).

January – In Laos, King Anouvong of Vientiane leads the Laotian Rebellion against Siam and successfully attacks Nakhon Ratchasima (the Siamese later invade Vientiane and nearly destroy the whole city).
January  – Jean Baptiste Gay, vicomte de Martignac succeeds the Comte de Villèle, as Prime Minister of France.
January  – The Democratic Party of the United States is organized.
January  – Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington succeeds Lord Goderich as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

February  – "Black War": In the Cape Grim massacre – About  Aboriginal Tasmanians gathering food at a beach are probably ambushed, shot with muskets and killed by four indentured "servants" (or convicts) employed as shepherds for the Van Diemen's Land Company as part of a series of reprisal attacks, with the bodies of some of the men thrown from a  metre ( ft) cliff.
February  – The Boston Society for Medical Improvement is established in the United States.
January  – August Klingemann's adaptation of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe's Faust premieres in Braunschweig.
February  – Battle of Tarqui: Troops of Gran Colombia and Peru battle to a draw.

March  – German composer Felix Mendelssohn conducts the first performance of Johann Sebastian Bach's St Matthew Passion since the latter's death in , in Berlin; the success of this performance sparks a revival of interest in Bach.
March  – The bloodless Wellington–Winchilsea duel takes place at Battersea near London

March  – Greece receives autonomy from the Ottoman Empire in the London Protocol, signed by Russia, France and Britain, effectively ending the Greek War of Independence. Greece continues to seek full independence through diplomatic negotiations with the three Great Powers.
January  – LaGrange College (later the University of North Alabama) begins operation, becoming the first publicly chartered college in Alabama.

January  – Webster–Hayne debate: In the United States Congress, Robert Y. Hayne of South Carolina debates against Daniel Webster of Massachusetts about the question of states' rights vs. federal authority. The debate lasts until –January .
February  – The London Protocol establishes the full independence and sovereignty of Greece from the Ottoman Empire, as the result of the Greek War of Independence.

February  – A fire destroys the Argyll Rooms in London, where the Philharmonic Society of London presents concerts, but firefighters are able to prevent its further spread by use of their new equipment, steam-powered fire engines.

March  – The Book of Mormon, subtitled "An Account Written by the Hand of Mormon, Upon Plates Taken from the Plates of Nephi",  is first published, with E. B. Grandin printing the original edition in Palmyra, New York.
January  – William Lloyd Garrison begins publishing The Liberator, an anti-slavery newspaper, in Boston, Massachusetts.
January  – Japanese department store, Takashimaya in Kyoto established.
February–March – Revolts in Modena, Parma and the Papal States are put down by Austrian troops.
February  – Pope Gregory XVI succeeds Pope Pius VIII, as the 254th pope.
February  – Dutch naval lieutenant Jan van Speyk blows up his own gunboat in Antwerp rather than strike his colours on the demand of supporters of the Belgian Revolution.
January  – Abolitionist William Lloyd Garrison founds the New-England Anti-Slavery Society.

January  – The Christmas Rebellion of slaves is brought to an end in Jamaica, after the island's white planters organize militias and the British Army sends companies of the 84th regiment to enforce martial law.  More than  of the slave rebels will be publicly hanged for their part in the destruction.
February  – The Swan River Colony is renamed Western Australia.
February  – The Florida Legislative Council grants a city charter for Jacksonville, Florida.

February 
Ecuador annexes the Galápagos Islands.
A cholera epidemic in London claims at least , lives; the contagion spreads to France and North America later this year.
January  – The United Kingdom reasserts British sovereignty over the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic Ocean.
February  (January  on the Greek calendar) – Prince Otto Friedrich Ludwig of Bavaria arrives at the port of Nafplio to assume the title King Othon the First of Greece
February  – The United States Supreme Court hands down its landmark decision of Barron v. Mayor and City Council of Baltimore.

April  – General Antonio López de Santa Anna is elected President of Mexico by the legislatures of  of the  Mexican states. During his frequent absences from office to fight on the battlefield, Santa Anna turns the duties of government over to his vice president, Valentín Gómez Farías.

April  – Over  delegates from England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland travel to the office of the Prime Minister, the Earl Grey, to call for the immediate abolition of slavery throughout the British Empire.
January  – Zollverein (Germany): Customs charges are abolished at borders within its member states.
January  – The government of Mexico imprisons Stephen F. Austin in Mexico City.
January – The Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad is chartered in Wilmington, North Carolina.
February  – Wake Forest University is founded as the Wake Forest Manual Labor Institute in Wake Forest, North Carolina.
February  – Freed American slaves from Maryland form a settlement in Cape Palmas, it is named the Republic of Maryland.
January  – HMS Beagle anchors off the Chonos Archipelago on her second voyage, with Charles Darwin on board as naturalist.
January  – The United States public debt contracts to zero, for the only time in history.
January  – Malê Revolt: African slaves of Yoruba Muslim origin revolt against Brazilian owners at Salvador, Bahia.

January 
Queen Maria II of Portugal marries Auguste de Beauharnais, 2nd Duke of Leuchtenberg, in Lisbon; he dies only two months later.
Saint Paul's in Macau is largely destroyed by fire after a typhoon hits.
Queen Maria II of Portugal marries Auguste de Beauharnais, 2nd Duke of Leuchtenberg, in Lisbon; he dies only two months later.
January  — Hill Street Academy is named Colombo Academy and acquired by the Government, establishing the first public school in Sri Lanka.
January  – Queen Maria II of Portugal marries Prince Ferdinand Augustus Francis Anthony of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha.
January  – Former U.S. Representative Davy Crockett of Tennessee arrives in Texas to join the Texan fight for independence from Mexico.

January 
HMS Beagle, with Charles Darwin on board, reaches Sydney.
Will County, Illinois, is formed.
HMS Beagle, with Charles Darwin on board, reaches Sydney.
January  – The destructive Galilee earthquake causes thousands of deaths in Ottoman Syria.
January  – Michigan becomes the 26th state admitted to the United States.
February  – Seminoles attack Fort Foster in Florida.
February  – In Philadelphia, the Institute for Colored Youth (ICY) is founded, as the first institution for the higher education of black people in the United States.
February – Charles Dickens's Oliver Twist begins publication in serial form in London.
January  – A fire destroys Lloyd's Coffee House and the Royal Exchange in London.
January  – At Morristown, New Jersey, Samuel Morse, Alfred Vail and Leonard Gale give the first public demonstration of Morse's new invention, the telegraph.
January  – The first known report about the lowest temperature on Earth is made, indicating − °C (− °F) in Yakutsk.
January  – A . earthquake strikes the Romanian district of Vrancea causing damage in Moldavia and  Wallachia, killing  people.

February  – Boer explorer Piet Retief and  of his men are massacred by King Dingane kaSenzangakhona of the Zulu people, after Retief accepts an invitation to celebrate the signing of a treaty, and his men willingly disarm as a show of good faith.
January  – The first photograph of the Moon is taken, by French photographer Louis Daguerre.
January  – Night of the Big Wind: Ireland is struck by the most damaging cyclone in  years.
January  – The French Academy of Sciences announces the daguerreotype photography process.
January  – The British Aden Expedition captures Aden.
January  – Battle of Yungay: Chile defeats the Peru–Bolivian Confederation, leading to the restoration of an independent Peru.
January  – One of the predecessor papers of the Herald Sun of Melbourne, Australia, The Port Phillip Herald, is founded.
January  – Uniform Penny Post is introduced in the United Kingdom.
January  – The steamship Lexington burns and sinks in icy waters, four miles off the coast of Long Island;  die, only four survive.

January  – Captain Charles Wilkes' United States Exploring Expedition sights what becomes known as Wilkes Land in the southeast quadrant of Antarctica, claiming it for the United States, and providing evidence that Antarctica is a complete continent.
January  – Jules Dumont d'Urville discovers Adélie Land in Antarctica, claiming it for France.
January  – Charles Elliot of the United Kingdom and Qishan of the Qing dynasty agree to the Convention of Chuenpi.
January  – Britain occupies Hong Kong. Later in the year, the first census of the island records a population of about ,.
January  – The active volcano Mount Erebus in Antarctica is discovered, and named by James Clark Ross.
January  – Ross discovers the "Victoria Barrier", later known as the Ross Ice Shelf. On the same voyage, he discovers the Ross Sea, Victoria Land and Mount Terror.

January  –
El Salvador proclaims itself an independent republic, bringing an end to the  Federal Republic of Central America.
A fire destroys two-thirds of the city of Mayagüez, Puerto Rico.

January – – First Anglo-Afghan War – Massacre of Elphinstone's army (Battle of Gandamak): British East India Company troops are destroyed by Afghan forces on the road from Kabul to Jalalabad, Afghanistan, by Akbar Khan, son of Dost Mohammad Khan.
January  – Delft University of Technology is established by William II of the Netherlands, as a 'Royal Academy for the education of civilian engineers'.
January  – Antarctic explorer James Clark Ross, charting the eastern side of James Ross Island, reaches a Farthest South of °'"S.

January
Michael Alexander takes office, as the first appointee to the Anglican-German Bishopric in Jerusalem.
American medical student William E. Clarke of Berkshire Medical College becomes the first person to administer an inhaled anesthetic, to facilitate a surgical procedure. After Clarke uses a towel and ether to anesthetize a patient identified as "Miss Hobbie", Dr. Elijah Pope pulls her tooth.
Michael Alexander takes office, as the first appointee to the Anglican-German Bishopric in Jerusalem.
January  – The Illustrated Treatise on the Maritime Kingdoms (海國圖志, Hǎiguó Túzhì) compiled by Wei Yuan and others, the first significant Chinese work on the West, is published in China.
January  – Antarctic explorer James Clark Ross discovers Snow Hill Island.

January  – Honório Hermeto Carneiro Leão, Marquis of Paraná is appointed by the Emperor, Dom Pedro, as the leader of the Brazilian Council of Ministers, although the office of Prime Minister of Brazil will not be officially created until .

January
Serial publication of Charles Dickens's novel Martin Chuzzlewit begins in London; in the July chapters, he lands his hero in the United States.
Edgar Allan Poe's short story "The Tell-Tale Heart" is published in The Pioneer, a Boston magazine.
The Quaker magazine The Friend is first published in London.
Serial publication of Charles Dickens's novel Martin Chuzzlewit begins in London; in the July chapters, he lands his hero in the United States.
January  – The first issue of the Swedish-languaged Saima newspaper founded by J. V. Snellman is published in Kuopio, Finland.
January  – The University of Notre Dame, based in the city of the same name, receives its charter from Indiana.
February  – The Dominican Republic gains independence from Haiti.

February  – A gun on the USS Princeton explodes while the boat is on a Potomac River cruise, killing U.S. Secretary of State Abel Upshur, U.S. Secretary of the Navy Thomas Walker Gilmer and four other people. President John Tyler is below decks and is uninjured.

March 
King Oscar I ascends to the throne of Sweden–Norway upon the death of his father, Charles XIV/III John.
The Althing, the parliament of Iceland, is reopened after  years of closure.

January  – The Philippines began reckoning Asian dates by hopping the International Date Line through skipping Tuesday, December , . That time zone shift was a reform made by Governor–General Narciso Claveria on August , , in order to align the local calendars in the country with the rest of Asia as trade interests with Imperial China, Dutch East Indies and neighboring countries increased, after Mexico became independent in . The reform also applied to Caroline Islands, Guam, Marianas Islands, Marshall Islands, and Palau as part of the Captaincy General of the Philippines.
January  – Elizabeth Barrett receives a love letter from the younger poet Robert Browning; on May , they meet for the first time in London. She begins writing her Sonnets from the Portuguese.
January  – The United States Congress establishes a uniform date for federal elections, which will henceforth be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November.
January  – The Raven by Edgar Allan Poe is published for the first time, in the New York Evening Mirror.

February  – Anson Jones, President of the Republic of Texas, signs the charter officially creating Baylor University (the oldest university in the U.S. state of Texas that still operates under its original name).
January  – The United States House of Representatives votes to stop sharing the Oregon Country with the United Kingdom.
January  – The Milan–Venice railway's . km (. mi) bridge, over the Venetian Lagoon between Mestre and Venice in Italy, opens, the world's longest since .
January  – Ahmad I ibn Mustafa, Bey of Tunis, declares the legal abolition of slavery in Tunisia.
February  – Led by Brigham Young, many Mormons in the U.S. begin their migration west from Nauvoo, Illinois, to the Great Salt Lake in what becomes Utah.
February  – First Anglo-Sikh war: Battle of Sobraon – British forces in India defeat the Sikhs.
January  – Samuel Colt sells his first revolver pistol to the U.S. government.
January  – The Treaty of Cahuenga ends fighting in the Mexican–American War in California.
January  – John C. Frémont is appointed Governor of the new California Territory.
January  – St. Anthony Hall fraternity is founded at Columbia University, New York City.
January  – Yerba Buena, California, is renamed San Francisco.
January  – Joseph Jenkins Roberts is sworn in as the first president of the independent African Republic of Liberia.
January  – Sicilian revolution of : The Palermo rising erupts in Sicily against the Bourbon Kingdom of the Two Sicilies.
January  – California Gold Rush: James W. Marshall finds gold at Sutter's Mill, in Coloma, California.

January  – In the United States:
Construction of the Washington Monument begins in Washington, D.C.
John C. Frémont is court-martialed on grounds of mutiny and disobeying orders. The verdict is set aside by U.S. President James K. Polk, but Frémont retires to California Territory.
Construction of the Washington Monument begins in Washington, D.C.
January  – France begins issue of the Ceres series, the nation's first postage stamps.

January  – Hungarian Revolution of : The Austrian army, led by Alfred I, Prince of Windisch-Grätz, enters in the Hungarian capitals, Buda and Pest. The Hungarian government and parliament flee to Debrecen.
January  – Hungarian Revolution of : Romanian armed groups massacre  unarmed Hungarian civilians, at Nagyenyed.

January 
Second Anglo-Sikh War – Battle of Tooele: British forces retreat from the Sikhs.
The Colony of Vancouver Island is established.
Second Anglo-Sikh War – Battle of Tooele: British forces retreat from the Sikhs.
January  – Henry Clay introduces the Compromise of  to the United States Congress.
January  – The University of Rochester is founded in Rochester, New York.
January – Sacramento floods.
February  - Abraham Lincoln’s second son, Edward Lincoln, died at the age of three after  days for struggling with tuberculosis (consumption) before his fourth birthday in Springfield, Illinois.
February  – The University of Utah opens in Salt Lake City.
January  – Hong Xiuquan officially begins the Taiping Rebellion in China, one of the bloodiest revolts that would lead to  million deaths.
January  – Christian Female College, modern-day Columbia College, receives its charter from the Missouri General Assembly.

January  – The flip of a coin, subsequently named the Portland Penny, determines whether a new city in the Oregon Territory will be named after Boston, Massachusetts, or Portland, Maine, with Portland winning.
January  – Northwestern University is founded in Illinois.
February  – Brandtaucher, the oldest surviving submersible craft, sinks during acceptance trials in the German port of Kiel, but the designer, Wilhelm Bauer, and the two crew escape successfully.
January  – President Louis-Napoléon Bonaparte proclaims a new constitution for the French Second Republic.
January  – Nine men representing various Jewish charitable organizations come together to form what will become Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City.
January  – The United Kingdom recognizes the independence of the Transvaal.

February  – Battle of Caseros, Argentina: The Argentine provinces of Entre Rios and Corrientes, allied with Brazil and members of Colorado Party of Uruguay, defeat Buenos Aires troops under Juan Manuel de Rosas.
February  – The first British public toilet for women opens in Bedford Street, London.

January 
Florida Governor Thomas Brown signs legislation that provides public support for the new East Florida Seminary, leading to the establishment of the University of Florida.
U.S. President-elect Franklin Pierce's only living child, Benjamin "Benny" Pierce, is killed in a train accident.
Florida Governor Thomas Brown signs legislation that provides public support for the new East Florida Seminary, leading to the establishment of the University of Florida.
U.S. President-elect Franklin Pierce's only living child, Benjamin "Benny" Pierce, is killed in a train accident.
January  – Taiping Rebellion: Zeng Guofan is ordered to assist the governor of Hunan in organizing a militia force to search for local bandits.
January  – Taiping Rebellion: The Taiping army occupies Wuchang.
January  – The McDonald Islands are discovered by Captain William McDonald aboard the Samarang.
January  – The fictional detective Sherlock Holmes is perhaps born.
January  – The Teutonia Männerchor in Pittsburgh is founded to promote German culture.

January  – The North Carolina General Assembly in the United States charters the Atlantic and North Carolina Railroad, to run from Goldsboro through New Bern, to the newly created seaport of Morehead City, near Beaufort.
January  – The iron clipper RMS Tayleur runs aground off the east coast of Ireland, on her maiden voyage out of Liverpool, bound for Australia, with the loss of at least  out of  on board.
January  – Ottawa, Ontario, is incorporated as a city.'
January  – Ramón Castilla begins his third term as President of Peru.

January 
The first bridge over the Mississippi River opens in modern-day Minneapolis, a predecessor of the Father Louis Hennepin Bridge.
The .–. Mw  Wairarapa earthquake claims between five and nine lives near the Cook Strait area of New Zealand.
The first bridge over the Mississippi River opens in modern-day Minneapolis, a predecessor of the Father Louis Hennepin Bridge.
The .–. Mw  Wairarapa earthquake claims between five and nine lives near the Cook Strait area of New Zealand.
January  – Borax deposits are discovered in large quantities by John Veatch in California.
January  – The American sidewheel steamer SS Pacific leaves Liverpool (England) for a transatlantic voyage on which she will be lost with all  on board.
January  – U.S. President Franklin Pierce declares the new Free-State Topeka government in "Bleeding Kansas" to be in rebellion.
January  – First Battle of Seattle:  Marines from the USS Decatur suppress an indigenous uprising, in response to Governor Stevens' declaration of a "war of extermination" on Native communities.

January 
The -mile North Carolina Railroad is completed from Goldsboro through Raleigh and Salisbury to Charlotte.
Queen Victoria institutes the Victoria Cross as a British military decoration.
January  – The biggest Estonian newspaper, Postimees, is established by Johann Voldemar Jannsen.
January  – The partly French-owned London General Omnibus Company begins operating.
January  – The . Mw  Fort Tejon earthquake shakes Central and Southern California, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent).

January  – The University of Calcutta is established in Calcutta, as the first multidisciplinary modern university in South Asia. The University of Bombay is also established in Bombay, British India, this year.
February  – The National Deaf Mute College (later renamed Gallaudet University) is established in Washington, D.C., becoming the first school for the advanced education of the deaf.

January 
Revolt of Rajab Ali: British forces finally defeat Rajab Ali Khan of Chittagong.
Anson Jones, the last president of the Republic of Texas, commits suicide.
Revolt of Rajab Ali: British forces finally defeat Rajab Ali Khan of Chittagong.
Anson Jones, the last president of the Republic of Texas, commits suicide.

January  – Orsini affair: Piedmontese revolutionary Felice Orsini and his accomplices fail to assassinate Napoleon III in Paris, but their bombs kill eight and wound  people. Because of the involvement of French émigrés living in Britain, there is a brief anti-British feeling in France, but the emperor refuses to support it.

January  – The Wedding March by Felix Mendelssohn becomes a popular wedding recessional, after it is played on this day at the marriage of Queen Victoria's daughter Victoria, Princess Royal, to Prince Friedrich of Prussia in St James's Palace, London.
January  – José Mariano Salas (–) becomes Conservative interim President of Mexico.

January  (O. S.) – Under the rule of Alexandru Ioan Cuza, the provinces of Wallachia and Moldavia are united under the jurisdiction of the Ottoman Empire. It would be a principal step in forming the modern state of Romania.
January  – The city of Olympia is incorporated in the Washington Territory of the United States of America.
February  – Miguel Miramón (–) becomes Conservative interim President of Mexico.

February  – German scholar Constantin von Tischendorf rediscovers the Codex Sinaiticus, a 4th-century uncial manuscript of the Greek Bible, in Saint Catherine's Monastery on the foot of Mount Sinai, in the Khedivate of Egypt and arranges for its presentation to his patron, Tsar Alexander II of Russia at Saint Petersburg.
January  – The astronomer Urbain Le Verrier announces the discovery of a hypothetical planet Vulcan at a meeting of the French Academy of Sciences in Paris, France.
January  – The Pemberton Mill in Lawrence, Massachusetts collapses, killing at least  workers.
January  – Battle of Tétouan, Morocco: Spanish troops under General Leopoldo O'Donnell, 1st Duke of Tetuan defeat the Moroccan Army.
January  – Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour is recalled as Prime Minister of Piedmont-Sardinia.
February  – Canadian Royal Mail steamer SS Hungarian () is wrecked on Cape Sable Island, Nova Scotia, on passage from the British Isles to the United States with all  onboard lost.

January 
Benito Juárez captures Mexico City.
The first steam-powered carousel is recorded, in Bolton, England.
Benito Juárez captures Mexico City.
The first steam-powered carousel is recorded, in Bolton, England.
January  – Friedrich Wilhelm IV of Prussia dies, and is succeeded by Wilhelm I.

January  – Delaware votes not to secede from the Union.
January  – Mississippi becomes the second state to secede from the Union.
January  – Florida secedes from the Union.
January  – Alabama secedes from the Union.
January  – Major Robert Anderson sends dispatches to Washington.
January  – Georgia secedes from the Union.
January  – Jefferson Davis resigns from the United States Senate.
January  – Louisiana secedes from the Union.
January  – The United Kingdom annexes Lagos Island, in modern-day Nigeria.
January  – French intervention in Mexico: French, Spanish and British forces arrive in Veracruz, Mexico.
January  – Hartley Colliery disaster in north-east England:  men are trapped and die underground when the only shaft becomes blocked.
January  – American Civil War: The first U.S. ironclad warship, USS Monitor, is launched in Brooklyn.
January  – Alvan Graham Clark makes the first observation of Sirius B, a white dwarf star, through an eighteen-inch telescope at Northwestern University in Illinois.

January  – Abraham Lincoln signs the Emancipation Proclamation during the third year of the American Civil War, making the abolition of slavery in the Confederate States of America an official war goal. The signing proclaimed the freedom of . million of the nation's four million slaves and immediately frees , of them, with the rest freed as the Union Army advances. This event marks the start of America's Reconstruction Era.
January  – Master Lucius Tar Paint  Company (Teerfarbenfabrik Meister Lucius), predecessor of Hoechst, as a worldwide chemical manufacturing brand, founded in a suburb of Frankfurt am Main, Germany.
January  – Founding date of the New Apostolic Church, a Christian and chiliastic church, in a schism with the Catholic Apostolic Church in Hamburg, Germany.
January  – In the Swiss canton of Ticino, the village of Bedretto is partly destroyed and  killed by an avalanche.

January 
The Yorkshire County Cricket Club is founded at the Adelphi Hotel, in Sheffield, England.
American Civil War: The Second Battle of Springfield takes place near Springfield, Missouri. Fighting for the Union, General Egbert B. Brown leads the Missouri militia to victory over Confederate General John S. Marmaduke and the 18th Arkansas Infantry.

January  – American songwriter Stephen Foster ("Oh! Susanna", "Old Folks at Home") dies aged  in New York City, leaving a scrap of paper reading "Dear friends and gentle hearts". His parlor song "Beautiful Dreamer" is published in March.
January  – Denmark rejects an Austrian-Prussian ultimatum to repeal the Danish Constitution, which says that Schleswig-Holstein is part of Denmark.
January  – New Zealand Wars: The Tauranga campaign begins.
January  – the Stifone powder-magazine explosion near Narni, Italy, destroys much of the village of Stifone and kills  people.
February – John Wisden publishes The Cricketer's Almanack for the year  in England; it will go on to become the major annual cricket reference publication.
January  – The New York Stock Exchange opens its first permanent headquarters at - Broad near Wall Street, in New York City.
January  – American Civil War: Second Battle of Fort Fisher – Union forces launch a major amphibious assault against the last seaport held by the Confederates, Fort Fisher, North Carolina.
January  – American Civil War: Union forces capture Fort Fisher.

January 
The Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution (conditional prohibition of slavery and involuntary servitude) passes narrowly, in the House of Representatives.
American Civil War: Confederate General Robert E. Lee becomes general-in-chief.
The Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution (conditional prohibition of slavery and involuntary servitude) passes narrowly, in the House of Representatives.

January 
Fisk University, a historically black university, is established in Nashville, Tennessee.
The last issue of the abolitionist magazine The Liberator is published.
Fisk University, a historically black university, is established in Nashville, Tennessee.
The last issue of the abolitionist magazine The Liberator is published.
January  – Ottoman troops clash with supporters of Maronite leader Youssef Bey Karam, at St. Doumit in Lebanon; the Ottomans are defeated.

January 
The Royal Aeronautical Society is formed as The Aeronautical Society of Great Britain in London, the world's oldest such society.
British auxiliary steamer SS London () sinks in a storm in the Bay of Biscay, on passage from the Thames to Australia, with the loss of  people, and only  survivors.

January  – The Covington–Cincinnati Suspension Bridge opens between Cincinnati, Ohio, and Covington, Kentucky, in the United States, becoming the longest single-span bridge in the world. It is renamed after its designer, John A. Roebling, in .
January  – African-American men are granted the right to vote in the District of Columbia.
January  – Benito Juárez becomes Mexican president again.
January  – Regent's Park skating disaster in London:  people die when ice on a lake breaks.
January  – Emperor Kōmei of Japan dies suddenly, age , leaving his son Mutsuhito to succeed him.
January  – British Expedition to Abyssinia: Robert Napier leads an expedition to free captive British officials and missionaries.

January  – The -year-old Mutsuhito, Emperor Meiji of Japan, declares the Meiji Restoration, his own restoration to full power, under the influence of supporters from the Chōshū and Satsuma Domains, and against the supporters of the Tokugawa shogunate, triggering the Boshin War.

January  – Paraguayan War: Brazilian Army commander Luís Alves de Lima e Silva, Duke of Caxias, enters Asunción, Paraguay's capital. Some days later he declares the war is over. Nevertheless, Francisco Solano López, Paraguay's president, prepares guerrillas to fight in the countryside.
January  – The Arkansas constitutional convention meets in Little Rock.

January  – Penal transportation from Britain to Australia ends, with arrival of the convict ship Hougoumont in Western Australia, after an -day voyage from England. There are  Fenians among the transportees.
January  – Abdur Rahman Khan is defeated at Tinah Khan, and exiled from Afghanistan.
January  – Scotland's second oldest professional football team, Kilmarnock F.C., is founded.
January  – Elizabeth Cady Stanton is the first woman to testify before the United States Congress.
January  – The P.E.O. Sisterhood, a philanthropic educational organization for women, is founded at Iowa Wesleyan College in Mount Pleasant, Iowa.
January  – The Republic of Ezo is proclaimed on the northern Japanese island of Ezo (which will be renamed Hokkaidō on September ) by remaining adherents to the Tokugawa shogunate.

January 
The first edition of The Northern Echo newspaper is published in Priestgate, Darlington, England.
Plans for the Brooklyn Bridge are completed.
The first edition of The Northern Echo newspaper is published in Priestgate, Darlington, England.
Plans for the Brooklyn Bridge are completed.
January  – Construction of the Brooklyn Bridge begins in New York City.
January  – The Musikverein, Vienna, is inaugurated in Austria-Hungary.
January  – Franco-Prussian War: Battle of Bapaume – Prussians win a strategic victory.

January  – Proclamation of the German Empire: The member states of the North German Confederation and the south German states unite into a single nation state, known as the German Empire. The King of Prussia is declared the first German Emperor as Wilhelm I of Germany, in the Hall of Mirrors at the Palace of Versailles. The Constitution of the German Confederation comes into effect. It abolishes all restrictions on Jewish marriage, choice of occupation, place of residence, and property ownership, but exclusion from government employment and discrimination in social relations remain in effect.
January  – Battle of Dijon: Giuseppe Garibaldi's group of French and Italian volunteer troops, in support of the French Third Republic, win a battle against the Prussians.

February  –  French legislative election elects the first legislature of the French Third Republic; monarchists (Legitimists and Orleanists) favourable to peace with the German Empire gain a large majority. The National Assembly meets in Bordeaux.
February  – The United States Commission on Fish and Fisheries is founded.
January  – Yohannes IV is crowned Emperor of Ethiopia in Axum, the first ruler crowned in that city in over  years.
January  – The Cavite mutiny was an uprising of Filipino military personnel of Fort San Felipe, the Spanish arsenal in Cavite, Philippine Islands.
February  – The government of the United Kingdom buys a number of forts on the Gold Coast, from the Netherlands.
February  – A great solar flare, and associated geomagnetic storm, makes northern lights visible as far south as Cuba.
February  – Rex, the most famous parade on Mardi Gras, parades for the first time in New Orleans for Grand Duke Alexei Alexandrovich of Russia.

January 
Japan adopts the Gregorian calendar.
The California Penal Code goes into effect.
Japan adopts the Gregorian calendar.
The California Penal Code goes into effect.
January  – American Indian Wars: Modoc War: First Battle of the Stronghold – Modoc Indians defeat the United States Army.
February  – The Spanish Cortes deposes King Amadeus I, and proclaims the First Spanish Republic.
January  – New York City annexes The Bronx.
January  – Ignacio María González becomes head of state of the Dominican Republic for the first time.

January  – Third Carlist War: Battle of Caspe – Campaigning on the Ebro in Aragon for the Spanish Republican Government, Colonel Eulogio Despujol surprises a Carlist force under Manuel Marco de Bello at Caspe, northeast of Alcañiz. In a brilliant action the Carlists are routed, losing  prisoners and  horses, while Despujol is promoted to Brigadier and becomes Conde de Caspe.

January  – The Pangkor Treaty (also known as the Pangkor Engagement), by which the British extend their control over first the Sultanate of Perak, and later the other independent Malay States, is signed.

January  – Prince Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh, second son of Queen Victoria, marries Grand Duchess Maria Alexandrovna of Russia, only daughter of Tsar Alexander III of Russia, in the Grand Church of the Winter Palace in Saint Petersburg.

January  – The Midland Railway of England abolishes the Second Class passenger category, leaving First Class and Third Class. Other British railway companies follow Midland's lead during the rest of the year (Third Class is renamed Second Class in ).
January  – The Palais Garnier, one of the most famous opera houses in the world, is inaugurated as the home of the Paris Opera.
January  – Guangxu becomes the 11th Qing dynasty Emperor of China at the age of . He succeeds his cousin, the Tongzhi Emperor, who had no sons of his own.
January  – The newly proclaimed King Alfonso XII of Spain (Queen Isabella II's son) arrives in Spain to restore the monarchy during the Third Carlist War.
January  – Camille Saint-Saëns' orchestral Danse macabre receives its première.

January 
The Reichsbank opens in Berlin.
The Bass Brewery Red Triangle becomes the world's first registered trademark symbol, in the United Kingdom.
The Reichsbank opens in Berlin.
The Bass Brewery Red Triangle becomes the world's first registered trademark symbol, in the United Kingdom.
January  – The Northampton Bank robbery occurs in Massachusetts.

February 
The National League of Professional Base Ball Clubs is formed at a meeting in Chicago; it replaces the National Association of Professional Base Ball Players. Morgan Bulkeley of the Hartford Dark Blues is selected as the league's first president.
Third Carlist War (Spain): Battle of Montejurra – The new commander General Fernando Primo de Rivera marches on the remaining Carlist stronghold at Estella, where he meets a force of about , men under General Carlos Calderón, at nearby Montejurra. After a courageous and costly defence, Calderón is forced to withdraw.
January  – Queen Victoria is proclaimed Empress of India by the Royal Titles Act , introduced by Benjamin Disraeli, the prime minister of the United Kingdom .
January  – Great Sioux War of : Battle of Wolf Mountain – Crazy Horse and his warriors fight their last battle with the United States Cavalry in Montana.
January  – The Constantinople Conference ends, with Ottoman Turkey rejecting proposals of internal reform and Balkan provisions.

January  – The Satsuma Rebellion, a revolt of disaffected samurai in Japan, breaks out against the new imperial government; it lasts until September, when it is crushed by a professionally led army of draftees.
February  – Major General Charles George Gordon of the British Army is appointed Governor-General of the Sudan.
January  – Russo-Turkish War: Battle of Shipka Pass IV – Russian and Bulgarian forces defeat the Ottoman Empire.
January  – Umberto I becomes King of Italy.
January  – Russo-Turkish War: Battle of Philippopolis – Russian troops defeat the Ottoman Empire.
January  – Benjamin Disraeli orders the British fleet to the Dardanelles.
January  – Russian revolutionary Vera Zasulich shoots at Fyodor Trepov, Governor of Saint Petersburg.

January 
The Specie Resumption Act takes effect. The United States Note is valued the same as gold, for the first time since the American Civil War.
Brahms' Violin Concerto is premiered in Leipzig with Joseph Joachim as soloist and the composer conducting.
The Specie Resumption Act takes effect. The United States Note is valued the same as gold, for the first time since the American Civil War.
Brahms' Violin Concerto is premiered in Leipzig with Joseph Joachim as soloist and the composer conducting.
January  – The Anglo-Zulu War begins.
January  – Anglo-Zulu War – Battle of Isandlwana: A force of , British soldiers is wiped out by over , Zulu warriors.January : Battle of Isandlwana

January  – Thomas Edison is granted a patent for the incandescent light bulb. Edison filed for a US patent for an electric lamp using "a carbon filament or strip coiled and connected ... to platina contact wires." Although the patent described several ways of creating the carbon filament, including using "cotton and linen thread, wood splints, papers coiled in various ways," Edison and his team later discovered that a carbonized bamboo filament could last more than  hours.

January
The international White slave trade affair scandal in Brussels is exposed and attracts international infamy.
The Gokstad ship is found in Norway, the first Viking ship burial to be excavated.
The international White slave trade affair scandal in Brussels is exposed and attracts international infamy.
The Gokstad ship is found in Norway, the first Viking ship burial to be excavated.

February 
The first electric streetlight is installed in Wabash, Indiana.
The first successful shipment of frozen mutton from Australia arrives in London, aboard the SS Strathleven.
January – – Siege of Geok Tepe: Russian troops under General Mikhail Skobelev defeat the Turkomans.
January  – War of the Pacific – Battle of San Juan and Chorrillos: The Chilean army defeats Peruvian forces.
January  – War of the Pacific – Battle of Miraflores: The Chileans take Lima, capital of Peru, after defeating its second line of defense in Miraflores.

January  – William Edward Forster, chief secretary for Ireland, introduces his Coercion Bill, which temporarily suspends habeas corpus so that those people suspected of committing an offence can be detained without trial; it goes through a long debate before it is accepted February . Note that Coercion bills had been passed almost annually in the , with a total of  such bills passed from  to .
January  – Thomas Edison and Alexander Graham Bell form the Oriental Telephone Company.

January 
The Standard Oil Trust is secretly created in the United States to control multiple corporations set up by John D. Rockefeller and his associates.
Irish-born author Oscar Wilde arrives in New York at the beginning of a lecture tour of the United States and Canada.
The Standard Oil Trust is secretly created in the United States to control multiple corporations set up by John D. Rockefeller and his associates.
Irish-born author Oscar Wilde arrives in New York at the beginning of a lecture tour of the United States and Canada.
January  – Holborn Viaduct power station in the City of London, the world's first coal-fired public electricity generating station, begins operation.
February  – American showman P. T. Barnum acquires the elephant Jumbo from the London Zoo.
January  – Life magazine is founded in Los Angeles, California, United States.
January  – A fire at the Newhall Hotel in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, United States, kills  people.
January  – The Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act, establishing the United States civil service, is passed.
January  –  The first electric lighting system employing overhead wires begins service in Roselle, New Jersey, United States, installed by Thomas Edison.
February  – Tokyo Electrical Lightning Grid, predecessor of Tokyo Electrical Power (TEPCO), one of the largest electrical grids in Asia and the world, is founded in Japan.
January  – The Fabian Society is founded in London to promote gradualist social progress.
January  – Gilbert and Sullivan's comic opera Princess Ida, a satire on feminism, premières at the Savoy Theatre, London.
January  – German microbiologist Robert Koch isolates Vibrio cholerae, the cholera bacillus, working in India.

January  – William Price attempts to cremate his dead baby son, Iesu Grist, in Wales. Later tried and acquitted on the grounds that cremation is not contrary to English law, he is thus able to carry out the ceremony (the first in the United Kingdom in modern times) on March , setting a legal precedent.

January – Arthur Conan Doyle's anonymous story "J. Habakuk Jephson's Statement" appears in the Cornhill Magazine (London). Based on the disappearance of the crew of the Mary Celeste in , many of the fictional elements introduced by Doyle come to replace the real events in the popular imagination.
January – – Sino-French War: Battle of Núi Bop – French troops under General Oscar de Négrier defeat a numerically superior Qing Chinese force, in northern Vietnam.
January  – Mahdist War in Sudan: Battle of Abu Klea – British troops defeat Mahdist forces.
January  – American inventor LaMarcus Adna Thompson patents a roller coaster.
January  – Irish rebels damage Westminster Hall and the Tower of London with dynamite.
January  – Mahdist War in Sudan: Troops loyal to Mahdi Muhammad Ahmad conquer Khartoum; British commander Charles George Gordon is killed.
January  – Upper Burma is formally annexed to British Burma, following its conquest in the Third Anglo-Burmese War of November .
January – – Robert Louis Stevenson's novella Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde is published in New York and London.

January  – A resolution is passed in the German Parliament to condemn the Prussian deportations, the politically motivated mass expulsion of ethnic Poles and Jews from Prussia, initiated by Otto von Bismarck.
January  – Modern field hockey is born with the formation of The Hockey Association in England.
January  – Karl Benz patents the first successful gasoline-driven automobile, the Benz Patent-Motorwagen (built in ).
January  – Louis Pasteur's anti-rabies treatment is defended in the Académie Nationale de Médecine, by Dr. Joseph Grancher.

January 
The United States Senate allows the United States Navy to lease Pearl Harbor as a naval base.
British emigrant ship Kapunda sinks after a collision off the coast of Brazil, killing  with only  survivors.

British emigrant ship Kapunda sinks after a collision off the coast of Brazil, killing  with only  survivors.

January 
The Amateur Athletic Union (AAU) is formed in the United States.
Brisbane receives a one-day rainfall of  millimetres (. in) (a record for any Australian capital city).
January  – The great telescope (with an objective lens of  cm ( in) diameter) at Lick Observatory in California is first used.
January  – The Schoolhouse Blizzard hits Dakota Territory and the states of Montana, Minnesota, Nebraska, Kansas and Texas, leaving  dead, many of them children on their way home from school.
January  – The National Geographic Society is founded in Washington, D.C.
January  – The Battle of the Grapevine Creek, the last major conflict of the Hatfield–McCoy feud in the Southeastern United States.
January  – The Amateur Athletic Union is founded by William Buckingham Curtis in the United States.

January 
The total solar eclipse of January ,  is seen over parts of California and Nevada.
Paiute spiritual leader Wovoka experiences a vision, leading to the start of the Ghost Dance movement in the Dakotas.
The total solar eclipse of January ,  is seen over parts of California and Nevada.
