January  – An Act to Regulate Appointments in the Marine Hospital Service of the United States is signed by President Grover Cleveland. It establishes a Commissioned Corps of officers, as a predecessor to the modern-day U.S. Public Health Service Commissioned Corps.
January  – Herman Hollerith receives a patent for his electric tabulating machine in the United States.
January  – The Kingdom of Italy establishes Eritrea as its colony in the Horn of Africa.
January  – Alice Sanger becomes the first female staffer in the White House.

January  –  British Ultimatum: The United Kingdom demands Portugal withdraw its forces from the land between the Portuguese colonies of Mozambique and Angola (most of present-day Zimbabwe and Zambia).
January  – Ballet The Sleeping Beauty, with music by Tchaikovsky, is premiered at the Imperial Mariinsky Theatre in St. Petersburg, Russia.

January 
The United Mine Workers of America is founded.
American journalist Nellie Bly completes her round-the-world journey in  days.

January 
A strike of  Hungarian steel workers occurs; , men are out of work as a consequence.
Germany takes formal possession of its new African territories.
A strike of  Hungarian steel workers occurs; , men are out of work as a consequence.
Germany takes formal possession of its new African territories.
January  – The Earl of Zetland issues a declaration regarding the famine in the western counties of Ireland.

January 
The Australian shearers' strike, that leads indirectly to the foundation of the Australian Labor Party, begins.
A fight between the United States and Lakota people breaks out near Pine Ridge agency.
A fight between railway strikers and police breaks out at Motherwell, Scotland.
January  – Ellis Island begins processing immigrants to the United States.
February  – Rudolf Diesel applies for a patent, on his compression ignition engine (the Diesel engine).
February  – St. Petersburg, Florida is incorporated as a town.
March  – Theodoros Deligiannis ends his term as Prime Minister of Greece and Konstantinos Konstantopoulos takes office.

March – – Exclusive Agreement: Rulers of six Trucial States (Abu Dhabi, Dubai, Sharjah, Ajman, Ras al-Khaimah and Umm al-Quwain) and Bahrain sign an agreement, by which they become de facto British protectorates.
January  – Webb C. Ball introduces railroad chronometers, which become the general railroad timepiece standards in North America.
January  – The Washington National Cathedral is chartered by Congress; the charter is signed by President Benjamin Harrison.

January 
The Independent Labour Party of the United Kingdom has its first meeting.
U.S. Marines from the USS Boston land in Honolulu, Hawaii, to prevent the queen from abrogating the Bayonet Constitution.
The Independent Labour Party of the United Kingdom has its first meeting.
U.S. Marines from the USS Boston land in Honolulu, Hawaii, to prevent the queen from abrogating the Bayonet Constitution.
January  – A military alliance is established between the French Third Republic and the Russian Empire.
January  – William Kennedy Dickson receives a patent for motion picture film in the United States.
January  – New England Telephone and Telegraph installs the first battery-operated telephone switchboard, in Lexington, Massachusetts.
February  – French anarchist Émile Henry sets off a bomb in a Paris café, killing one person and wounding twenty.

February 
In Korea, peasant unrest erupts in the Donghak Peasant Revolution, a massive revolt of followers of the Donghak movement.  Both China and Japan send military forces, claiming to come to the ruling Joseon dynasty government's aid.
French anarchist Martial Bourdin dies of an accidental detonation of his own bomb, next to the Royal Observatory, Greenwich, in London, England.

January  – Dreyfus affair: French officer Alfred Dreyfus is stripped of his army rank and sentenced to life imprisonment on Devil's Island (off French Guiana) on what is much later admitted to be a false charge of treason.

January  – The Wilcox rebellion, an attempt led by Robert Wilcox to overthrow the Republic of Hawaii and restore the Kingdom of Hawaii, begins with royalist troops landing at Waikiki Beach in O'ahu and clashing with republican defenders. The rebellion ends after three days and the remaining  royalists are taken prisoners of war.
January  – Britain's National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty is founded by Octavia Hill, Robert Hunter and Canon Hardwicke Rawnsley.
January  – First Italo-Ethiopian War: Battle of Coatit – Italian forces defeat the Ethiopians.
January  – A warehouse fire and dynamite explosion kills  people, including  firefighters in Butte, Montana in the U.S.
January  – The Jameson Raid comes to an end as Jameson surrenders to the Boers.
January  – Utah is admitted as the 45th U.S. state.
January  – An Austrian newspaper reports Wilhelm Röntgen's discovery, last November, of a type of electromagnetic radiation, later known as X-rays.
January  – Cecil Rhodes is forced to resign as Prime Minister of the Cape of Good Hope for his involvement in the Jameson Raid.
January  – American culinary expert Fannie Farmer publishes her first cookbook.
January  – The International Alpha Omicron Pi sorority is founded, in New York City.
January  – A British force is ambushed by Chief Ologbosere, son-in-law of the ruler. This leads to a punitive expedition against Benin.
January  – A cyclone destroys Darwin, Australia.
January  – Lady Flora Shaw, future wife of Governor General Lord Lugard, officially proposes the name "Nigeria" in a newspaper contest, to be given to the British Niger Coast Protectorate.
January  – In this date's issue of the journal Engineering, the word computer is first used to refer to a mechanical calculation device.

January  – New York City annexes land from surrounding counties, creating the City of Greater New York as the world's second largest. The city is geographically divided into five boroughs: Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, The Bronx and Staten Island.

January  – Novelist Émile Zola's open letter to the President of the French Republic on the Dreyfus affair, J'Accuse…!, is published on the front page of the Paris daily newspaper L'Aurore, accusing the government of wrongfully imprisoning Alfred Dreyfus and of antisemitism.

February  – The automobile belonging to Henry Lindfield of Brighton rolls out of control down a hill in Purley, London, England, and hits a tree; thus he becomes the world's first fatality from an automobile accident on a public highway.

February  – Spanish–American War: The USS Maine explodes and sinks in Havana Harbor, Cuba, for reasons never fully established, killing  men. The event precipitates the United States' declaration of war on Spain, two months later.February : USS Maine is sunk.
February  – Émile Zola is imprisoned in France, after writing J'Accuse…!.

January 
Spanish rule formally ends in Cuba with the cession of Spanish sovereignty to the U.S., concluding  years of the Spanish Empire in the Americas.
In Samoa, followers of Mataafa, claimant to the rule of the island's subjects, burn the town of Upolu in an ambush of followers of other claimants, Malietoa Tanus and Tamasese, who are evacuated by the British warship HMS Porpoise.
Theodore Roosevelt is inaugurated as Governor of New York at the age of .

c. January – The first Michelin Guide is published for French motorists.

January  – Second Boer War: Boers attempt to end the Siege of Ladysmith, which leads to the Battle of Platrand.

January 
Puccini's opera Tosca premieres in Rome.
The U.S. Senate accepts the British-German Treaty of , in which the United Kingdom renounces its claims to the American Samoa portion of the Samoan Islands.

January 
The British colonies of New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria and Western Australia federate as the Commonwealth of Australia; Edmund Barton becomes the first Prime Minister of Australia.
Nigeria becomes a British protectorate.

January  – Lord Kitchener reports that Christiaan de Wet has shot one of the "peace" envoys, and flogged two more, who had gone to his commando to ask the Burgher citizens of South Africa to halt fighting.

January  – Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom dies at Osborne House on the Isle of Wight. She is  years old and, having ruled for nearly  years, will be the second longest-reigning monarch in British history. Her eldest son, Prince Albert Edward, "Bertie", the longest-serving Prince of Wales to this time, succeeds his mother at the age of , reigning as King Edward VII, of the United Kingdom and in innovation the British Dominions and also becoming Emperor of India.

January 
The Nurses Registration Act  comes into effect in New Zealand, making it the first country in the world to require state registration of nurses. On January , Ellen Dougherty becomes the world's first registered nurse.
Nathan Stubblefield demonstrates his wireless telephone device in the U.S. state of Kentucky.

January  – A train collision in the New York Central Railroad's Park Avenue Tunnel kills  people, injures , and leads to increased demand for electric trains and the banning of steam locomotives in New York City.
January  – Hakkōda Mountains incident: A snowstorm in the Hakkōda Mountains of northern Honshu, Japan, kills  during a military training exercise.
January  – Edward VII is proclaimed Emperor of India.
January  – The Aceh Sultanate was fully annexed by the Dutch forces, deposing the last sultan, marking the end of the Aceh War that have lasted for almost  years.
January  – The first west–east transatlantic radio broadcast is made from the United States to England (the first east–west broadcast having been made in ).

February  – Venezuelan crisis: After agreeing to arbitration in Washington, the United Kingdom, Germany and Italy reach a settlement with Venezuela resulting in the Washington Protocols. The naval blockade that began in  ends.
February  – Cuba leases Guantánamo Bay to the United States "in perpetuity".
January  – The distress signal CQD is established, only to be replaced  years later by SOS.
January  – The Herero Wars in German South West Africa begin.
January  – Anton Chekhov's last play, The Cherry Orchard, opens at the Moscow Art Theatre directed by Constantin Stanislavski.
January  – The Ålesund fire destroys most buildings in the town of Ålesund, Norway, leaving about , people without shelter.

January  – Halford Mackinder presents a paper on "The Geographical Pivot of History" to the Royal Geographical Society of London in which he formulates the Heartland Theory, originating the study of geopolitics.
January  – In a major defeat in the Russo-Japanese War, Russian General Anatoly Stessel surrenders Port Arthur, located on mainland China, to the Japanese.
January  – Japan formally repossesses Port Arthur, and renames it Ryojun, holding it for the next  years. The area will revert in  to China, and become the Lushunkou District.

January 
Gheorghe Grigore Cantacuzino becomes Prime Minister of Romania for the second time, having previously served from  to , and remains in office for more than two years.
The city of Bend, Oregon, plotted out in  by Alexander Drake, is incorporated as a town for local logging companies, and will have a population of  in . By the year , it will have almost , residents.

January  – Persian Constitutional Revolution: A nationalistic coalition of merchants, religious leaders and intellectuals in Persia forces the shah Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar to grant a constitution, and establish a national assembly, the Majlis.
January –April  – The Algeciras Conference convenes, to resolve the First Moroccan Crisis between France and Germany.
January  – The SS Valencia strikes a reef off Vancouver Island, Canada, killing over  (officially ) in the ensuing disaster.
January  – The Ecuador–Colombia earthquake (. on the Moment magnitude scale), and associated tsunami, cause at least  deaths.
February  – HMS Dreadnought is launched, sparking a naval race between Britain and Germany.
January  –  Kingston earthquake: A . Mw earthquake in Kingston, Jamaica, kills between  and ,.
February  – The "Mud March", the first large procession organised by The National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies (NUWSS), takes place in London.
February  – The French warship Jean Bart sinks off the coast of Morocco.
February  – The steamship Larchmont collides with the Harry Hamilton in Long Island Sound;  lives are lost.
February  – SKF, a worldwide mechanical parts manufacturing brand is founded in Gothenburg, Sweden.
January  – The British Nimrod Expedition led by Ernest Shackleton sets sail from New Zealand on the Nimrod for Antarctica.
January  – A total solar eclipse is visible in the Pacific Ocean and is the 46th solar eclipse of Solar Saros .
January  – A fire breaks out at the Rhoads Opera House in Boyertown, Pennsylvania, killing  people.
January  – Alpha Kappa Alpha, the  first race inclusive sorority is founded on the campus of Howard University in Washington, D.C.
January  – Robert Baden-Powell's Scouting for Boys begins publication in London. The book eventually sells over  million copies, and effectively begins the worldwide Boy Scout movement.
January  – Colombia recognizes the independence of Panama.

January  – The British Nimrod Expedition to the South Pole, led by Ernest Shackleton, arrives at the farthest south reached by any prior expedition, at °' S, prior to turning back due to diminishing supplies.
January  – The International Joint Commission on US-Canada boundary waters is established.
January  – Members of the Nimrod Expedition claim to have found the magnetic South Pole (but the location recorded may be incorrect).
January  – The White Star Liner RMS Republic sinks the day after a collision with SS Florida off Nantucket. Almost all of the , passengers are rescued.
January  – Abé people in the French West Africa colony of Côte d'Ivoire rise against the colonial administration; the rebellion is brutally suppressed by the military.
January  – Treaty of Punakha: The Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan becomes a protectorate of the British Empire.
January  – Charcot Island is discovered by the Antarctic expedition led by French explorer Jean-Baptiste Charcot on the ship Pourquoi Pas? Charcot returns from his expedition on February .
January  – Great January Comet of  first observed (perihelion: January ).

January  – Amidst the constitutional crisis caused by the House of Lords rejecting the People's Budget the January  United Kingdom general election is held resulting in a hung parliament with neither Liberals nor Conservatives gaining a majority.
January  – A decade after federation, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory are added to the Commonwealth of Australia.

January 
 Kebin earthquake: An earthquake of . moment magnitude strikes near Almaty in Russian Turkestan, killing  or more people.
Siege of Sidney Street in London: Two Latvian anarchists die, after a seven-hour siege against a combined police and military force. Home Secretary Winston Churchill arrives to oversee events.

January 
German geophysicist Alfred Wegener first presents his theory of continental drift.
New Mexico becomes the 47th U.S. state.

January – Joseph Stalin travels to Vienna to research his Marxism and the National Question. This means that, during this month, Stalin, Hitler, Trotsky and Tito are all living in the city, as also are Freud and Jung.
January  – First Balkan War: Greece completes its capture of the eastern Aegean island of Chios, as the last Ottoman forces on the island surrender.
January  – Edward Carson founds the (first) Ulster Volunteer Force, by unifying several existing loyalist militias to resist home rule for Ireland.

January  – First Balkan War: Battle of Lemnos – Greek admiral Pavlos Kountouriotis forces the Turkish fleet to retreat to its base within the Dardanelles, from which it will not venture for the rest of the war.
January  –  Ottoman coup d'état: Enver Pasha comes to power.

January  – The St. Petersburg–Tampa Airboat Line in the United States starts services between St. Petersburg and Tampa, Florida, becoming the first airline to provide scheduled regular commercial passenger services with heavier-than-air aircraft, with Tony Jannus (the first federally-licensed pilot) conveying passengers in a Benoist XIV flying boat. Abram C. Pheil, mayor of St. Petersburg, is the first airline passenger, and over , people witness the first departure.

January 
The Sakurajima volcano in Japan begins to erupt, becoming effusive after a very large earthquake on January . The lava flow causes the island which it forms to be linked to the Ōsumi Peninsula.
The Karluk, flagship of the Canadian Arctic Expedition, sinks after being crushed by ice.

January – British physicist Sir Joseph Larmor publishes his observations on "The Influence of Local Atmospheric Cooling on Astronomical Refraction".

January 
WWI: British Royal Navy battleship HMS Formidable is sunk off Lyme Regis, Dorset, England, by an Imperial German Navy U-boat, with the loss of  crew.
WWI: Battle of Broken Hill: A train ambush near Broken Hill, Australia, is carried out by two men (claiming to be in support of the Ottoman Empire) who are killed, together with four civilians.

January  – Joseph E. Carberry sets an altitude record of , feet (, m), carrying Capt. Benjamin Delahauf Foulois as a passenger, in a fixed-wing aircraft.
January  – The British Royal Army Medical Corps carries out the first successful blood transfusion, using blood that has been stored and cooled.
January  – WWI: Gallipoli Campaign – The last British troops are evacuated from Gallipoli, as the Ottoman Empire prevails over a joint British and French operation to capture Constantinople.
January  – WWI: Erzurum Offensive – Russia defeats the Ottoman Empire.
January  – The Gilbert and Ellice Islands Colony, part of the British Empire, is established in modern-day Tuvalu and Kiribati.
January  – WWI: Battle of Wadi – Ottoman Empire forces defeat the British, during the Mesopotamian campaign in modern-day Iraq.
January  – WWI – Battle of Rafa: The last substantial Ottoman Army garrison on the Sinai Peninsula is captured by the Egyptian Expeditionary Force's Desert Column.
January  – Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition: Seven survivors of the Ross Sea party are rescued after being stranded for several months.
January  – Unknown saboteurs set off the Kingsland explosion at Kingsland (modern-day Lyndhurst, New Jersey), one of the events leading to United States involvement in WWI.
January  – The Danish West Indies is sold to the United States for $ million (equivalent to $ million in ).
January  – WWI: United States President Woodrow Wilson calls for "peace without victory" in Germany.
January –  flu pandemic: The "Spanish flu" (influenza) is first observed in Haskell County, Kansas.
January  – The Finnish Declaration of Independence is recognized by Soviet Russia, Sweden, Germany and France.
January  – American president Woodrow Wilson presents the Fourteen Points as a basis for peace negotiations to end the war.

January  – Battle of Bear Valley: U.S. troops engage Yaqui Native American warriors in a minor skirmish in Arizona.  This is one of the last battles of the American Indian Wars between the United States and Native Americans.

January 
The keel of HMS Hermes is laid in Britain, the first purpose-designed aircraft carrier to be laid down.
The Red Army (The Workers and Peasants Red Army) is formed in the Russian SFSR and Soviet Union.

January 
The Czechoslovak Legions occupy much of the self-proclaimed "free city" of Pressburg (later Bratislava), enforcing its incorporation into the new republic of Czechoslovakia.
HMY Iolaire sinks off the coast of the Hebrides;  people, mostly servicemen returning home to Lewis and Harris, are killed.

January – – Russian Civil War: The Red Army's Caspian-Caucasian Front begins the Northern Caucasus Operation against the White Army, but fails to make progress.

January  – The Faisal–Weizmann Agreement is signed by Emir Faisal (representing the Arab Kingdom of Hejaz) and Zionist leader Chaim Weizmann, for Arab–Jewish cooperation in the development of a Jewish homeland in Palestine, and an Arab nation in a large part of the Middle East.

January 
Polish–Soviet War: The Russian Red Army increases its troops along the Polish border from  divisions to .
Kauniainen in Finland, completely surrounded by the city of Espoo, secedes from Espoo as its own market town.

January  – Russian Civil War: The forces of Russian White Admiral Alexander Kolchak surrender in Krasnoyarsk; the Great Siberian Ice March ensues.

January 
The Treaty of Versailles takes effect, officially ending World War I.
The League of Nations Covenant enters into force. On January , the organization holds its first council meeting, in Paris.

January 
The Association football club Cruzeiro Esporte Clube, from Belo Horizonte, is founded as the multi-sports club Palestra Italia by Italian expatriates in Brazil.
The Spanish liner Santa Isabel breaks in two and sinks off Villa Garcia, Mexico, with the loss of  of the  people on board.

January  – The Marxist Left in Slovakia and the Transcarpathian Ukraine holds its founding congress in Ľubochňa.
January  – The first recorded public performance of the illusion of "sawing a woman in half" is given by English stage magician P. T. Selbit at the Finsbury Park Empire variety theatre in London.
January  – Dáil Éireann, the parliament of the Irish Republic, ratifies the Anglo-Irish Treaty by – votes.
January  – Arthur Griffith is elected President of Dáil Éireann, the day after Éamon de Valera resigns.
January  – The first successful insulin treatment of diabetes is made, by Frederick Banting in Toronto.
January  – Michael Collins becomes Chairman of the Provisional Government of the Irish Free State.
January  – Italian forces occupy Misrata, Libya; the reconquest of Libya begins.
January  – Lithuania begins the Klaipėda Revolt to annex the Klaipėda Region (Memel Territory).
January  – Despite strong British protests, troops from France and Belgium occupy the Ruhr area, to force Germany to make reparation payments.
January  (or ) – First flight of the first rotorcraft, Juan de la Cierva's Cierva C. autogyro, in Spain. (It is first demonstrated to the military on January .)

February  – Australian cricketer Bill Ponsford makes  runs to break the world record for the highest first-class cricket score for the first time in his third match at this level, at Melbourne Cricket Ground, giving the Victoria cricket team an innings total of ,.

February  – Billy Hughes, having resigned as Prime Minister of Australia, after the Country Party refuses to govern in coalition with him as the leader of the Nationalist Party, is succeeded by Stanley Bruce. A Liberal–National Coalition will persist in the politics of Australia for at least  years.
January  – Gopinath Saha shoots Ernest Day, whom he has mistaken for Sir Charles Tegart, the police commissioner of Calcutta, and is arrested soon after.
January – – Kuomintang in China holds its first National Congress, initiating a policy of alliance with the Soviet Union and the Chinese Communist Party.
January  – The Earl of Athlone is appointed Governor-General of the Union of South Africa, and High Commissioner for Southern Africa.
January  – Ramsay MacDonald becomes the first Labour Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
January  – The first Winter Olympics, the  Winter Olympics, open in Chamonix, in the French Alps.
January  – The Syrian Federation is officially dissolved, the State of Aleppo and the State of Damascus having been replaced by the State of Syria.
January  – Benito Mussolini makes a pivotal speech in the Italian Chamber of Deputies which will be regarded by historians as the beginning of his dictatorship.
January  – Nellie Tayloe Ross becomes the first female governor (Wyoming) in the United States. Fifteen days later, Miriam A. Ferguson becomes first female governor of Texas.
January  – Hjalmar Branting resigns as Prime Minister of Sweden because of ill health, and is replaced by the minister of trade, Rickard Sandler.
January –February  – The  serum run to Nome (the "Great Race of Mercy") relays diphtheria antitoxin by dog sled across the U.S. Territory of Alaska to combat an epidemic.
January  – Theodoros Pangalos declares himself dictator in Greece.

January 
Ibn Saud is crowned ruler of the Kingdom of Hejaz.
Crown Prince Nguyễn Phúc Vĩnh Thuy ascends the throne as Bảo Đại, the last monarch of the Nguyễn dynasty of the Kingdom of Vietnam.

January  – A British Broadcasting Company radio play by Ronald Knox about workers' revolution in London causes a panic among those who have not heard the preliminary announcement that it is a satire on broadcasting.
January  – The British Broadcasting Company becomes the British Broadcasting Corporation, when its royal charter of incorporation takes effect. John Reith becomes the first Director-General.

January 
The first transatlantic telephone call is made via radio from New York City, United States, to London, United Kingdom.
The Harlem Globetrotters exhibition basketball team play their first ever road game in Hinckley, Illinois.

January  – The Laurier Palace Theatre fire at a movie theatre in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, kills  children.
January – British bacteriologist Frederick Griffith reports the results of Griffith's experiment, indirectly demonstrating that DNA is the genetic material.
January  – Eastern Bloc emigration and defection: Boris Bazhanov, Joseph Stalin's personal secretary, crosses the border to Iran to defect from the Soviet Union.
January  – The OGPU arrests Leon Trotsky in Moscow; he assumes a status of passive resistance and is exiled with his family.
January  – The volcanic island Anak Krakatau appears.
February – The Ford River Rouge Complex at Dearborn, Michigan, an automobile plant begun in , is completed as the world's largest integrated factory.

January 
 January Dictatorship: King Alexander of the Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes suspends his country's constitution.
Albanian missionary sister Agnes Gonxha Bojaxhiu, later known as Mother Teresa, arrives in Calcutta from Ireland to begin her work in India.
January Dictatorship: King Alexander of the Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes suspends his country's constitution.
Albanian missionary sister Agnes Gonxha Bojaxhiu, later known as Mother Teresa, arrives in Calcutta from Ireland to begin her work in India.

January  – The first appearance of Hergé's Belgian comic book hero Tintin, as Tintin in the Land of the Soviets (Les Aventures de Tintin, reporter..., au pays des Soviets), begins serialization in the children's newspaper supplement, Le Petit Vingtième.
January  – The comic strip hero Popeye first appears in Thimble Theatre.

January  – The Moon moves into its nearest point to Earth, called perigee, at the same time as its fullest phase of the Lunar Cycle. This is the closest moon distance at , km (, mi) in recent history, and the next one will be on January , , at , km (, mi).
January  – The Indian National Congress declares this date as Independence Day, or as the day for Purna Swaraj (Complete Independence).
January  – The first patent for a field-effect transistor is granted in the United States, to Julius Edgar Lilienfeld.
January  – Pavel Molchanov launches a radiosonde from Slutsk in the Soviet Union.
February  – The Việt Nam Quốc Dân Đảng launch the Yên Bái mutiny in the hope of ending French colonial rule in Vietnam.
January  – South Dakota native Ernest Lawrence invents the cyclotron, used to accelerate particles to study nuclear physics.
January  – German pilot Elly Beinhorn begins her flight to Africa.
January  – Sir Isaac Isaacs is sworn in as the first Australian-born Governor-General of Australia.
January  – Mohandas Gandhi is again released from imprisonment in India.
January  – Pierre Laval forms a government in France.
January  – The British authorities in India arrest and intern Mahatma Gandhi and Vallabhbhai Patel.

January  – Sakuradamon Incident: Korean nationalist Lee Bong-chang fails in his effort to assassinate Emperor Hirohito of Japan. The Kuomintang's official newspaper runs an editorial expressing regret that the attempt failed, which is used by the Japanese as a pretext to attack Shanghai later in the month.
January  – Hattie W. Caraway of Arkansas becomes the first woman to be elected to the United States Senate, succeeding her late husband, Thaddeus Caraway, in a special election,
January  – The  Salvadoran peasant uprising begins; it is suppressed by the government of Maximiliano Hernández Martínez.
January  – Marshal Pietro Badoglio declares the end of Libyan resistance.
January  – Australian aviator Sir Charles Kingsford Smith makes the first commercial flight between Australia and New Zealand.
January  – The United States Congress votes in favour of Philippines independence, against the wishes of U.S. President Herbert Hoover.

January  – "Pakistan Declaration": Choudhry Rahmat Ali publishes (in Cambridge, UK) a pamphlet entitled Now or Never; Are We to Live or Perish Forever?, in which he calls for the creation of a Muslim state in northwest India that he calls "Pakstan"; this influences the Pakistan Movement.

January 
Nazi Party leader Adolf Hitler is appointed Chancellor of Germany by President of Germany Paul von Hindenburg.
Édouard Daladier forms a government in France in succession to Joseph Paul-Boncour. He is succeeded on October  by Albert Sarraut and on November  by Camille Chautemps.
Nazi Party leader Adolf Hitler is appointed Chancellor of Germany by President of Germany Paul von Hindenburg.
January  – The International Telecommunication Union, a specialist agency of the League of Nations, is established.
January  – The . Mw  Nepal–Bihar earthquake strikes Nepal and Bihar with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing an estimated ,–, people.
February  – French political crisis: The French far-right leagues rally in front of the Palais Bourbon, in an attempted coup d'état against the Third Republic.

Gaston Doumergue forms a new government in France.

January  – Italian premier Benito Mussolini and French Foreign Minister Pierre Laval conclude an agreement, in which each power agrees not to oppose the other's colonial claims.
January  – Amelia Earhart becomes the first person to successfully complete a solo flight from Hawaii to California, a distance of , mi (, km).
January  – A plebiscite in the Territory of the Saar Basin shows that .% of those voting wish to join Germany.
January  – The first canned beer is sold in Richmond, Virginia, United States, by Gottfried Krueger Brewing Company.
February  – Parker Brothers begins selling the board game Monopoly in the United States.
January  – The Prince of Wales succeeds to the throne of the United Kingdom as King Edward VIII, following the death of his father, George V, at Sandringham House.
January  – State funeral of George V of the United Kingdom. After a procession through London, he is buried at St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle.
February  – Radium E (bismuth-) becomes the first radioactive element to be made synthetically.
February  – The IV Olympic Winter Games open in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany.
February – – Second Italo-Ethiopian War: Battle of Amba Aradam – Italian forces gain a decisive tactical victory, effectively neutralizing the army of the Ethiopian Empire.
January  – Anastasio Somoza García becomes President of Nicaragua.
January  – Water levels begin to rise in the Ohio River in the United States, leading to the Ohio River flood of , which continues into February, leaving  million people homeless and  people dead.
January  – Spanish Civil War: The Second Battle of the Corunna Road ends inconclusively.

January  – Moscow Trials: Trial of the Anti-Soviet Trotskyist Center – In the Soviet Union  leading Communists go on trial, accused of participating in a plot led by Leon Trotsky to overthrow Joseph Stalin's regime, and assassinate its leaders.

January  – The Moscow Trial initiated on January  is concluded. Thirteen of the defendants are sentenced to death (including Georgy Pyatakov, Nikolay Muralov and Leonid Serebryakov), while the rest, including Karl Radek and Grigory Sokolnikov are sent to labor camps and later murdered. They were initially spared for implicating others, including Rykov, Bukharin and Tukhachevsky, setting the stage for further trials
January  – State-owned railway networks are created by merger, in France (SNCF) and the Netherlands (Nederlandse Spoorwegen – NS).
January  – King Farouk of Egypt marries Safinaz Zulficar, who becomes Queen Farida, in Cairo.
January  – The Honeymoon Bridge at Niagara Falls, New York, collapses as a result of an ice jam.

February 
Adolf Hitler abolishes the War Ministry and creates the Oberkommando der Wehrmacht (High Command of the Armed Forces), giving him direct control of the German military. In addition, he dismisses political and military leaders considered unsympathetic to his philosophy or policies. General Werner von Fritsch is forced to resign as Commander of Chief of the German Army following accusations of homosexuality, and replaced by General Walther von Brauchitsch. Foreign Minister Baron Konstantin von Neurath is dismissed, and replaced by Joachim von Ribbentrop.
Walt Disney's Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, the first cel-animated feature in motion picture history, is released in the United States, following a premiere on December  of the previous year.

January  – WWII: Two prisoners, British officer Airey Neave and Dutch officer Anthony Luteyn, escape from Colditz Castle in Germany. After travelling for three days, they reach the Swiss border.

January  – WWII:
Battle of Slim River: Japanese forces of the 5th Division, supported by tanks, sweep through sixteen miles of British defenses, shattering the exhausted 11th Indian Division and inflicting some , casualties.
Operation Typhoon, the German attempt to take Moscow, ends in failure.

January  – WWII:
Free French General Jean de Lattre de Tassigny is appointed to command French Army B, part of the Sixth United States Army Group in North Africa.

January 
United States President Franklin D. Roosevelt proposes a Second Bill of Rights for social and economic security, in his State of the Union address.
The Nazi German administration expands Kraków-Płaszów concentration camp into the larger standalone Konzentrationslager Plaszow bei Krakau in occupied Poland.

January  – WWII:
Germany begins Operation Bodenplatte, an attempt by the Luftwaffe to cripple Allied air forces in the Low Countries.
Chenogne massacre: German prisoners are allegedly killed by American forces near the village of Chenogne, Belgium.

January  – The first general election ever in Vietnam is held.
January  – The Allies of World War II recognize the Austrian republic with its  borders, and divide the country into four occupation zones.

The first meeting of the United Nations is held, at Methodist Central Hall Westminster in London.
Project Diana bounces radar waves off the Moon, measuring the exact distance between the Earth and the Moon, and proves that communication is possible between Earth and outer space, effectively opening the Space Age.

January–February – Winter of – in the United Kingdom: The worst snowfall in the country in the  causes extensive disruption of travel. Given the low ratio of private vehicle ownership at the time, it is mainly remembered in terms of its effects on the railway network.
January  – The Canadian Citizenship Act comes into effect, providing a Canadian citizenship separate from British law.
January  – First issue of weekly magazine Der Spiegel published in Hanover, Germany, edited by Rudolf Augstein.
January  – The United Nations adopts a resolution to take control of the free city of Trieste.
January  – The Afghan tribal revolts of – conclude with the Surrender at Datta Khel.

The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) is inaugurated.
The current Constitutions of Italy and of New Jersey (both later subject to amendment) go into effect.
The railways of Britain are nationalized, to form British Railways.

January  – Burma gains its independence from the United Kingdom, becoming an independent republic, named the 'Union of Burma', with Sao Shwe Thaik as its first President and U Nu its first Prime Minister.
January  – A United Nations-sponsored ceasefire brings an end to the Indo-Pakistani War of . The war results in a stalemate and the division of Kashmir, which still continues as of
January  – Luis Muñoz Marín becomes the first democratically elected Governor of Puerto Rico.
January  – The first "networked" television broadcasts take place, as KDKA-TV in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, goes on the air, connecting east coast and mid-west programming in the United States.
January  – Şemsettin Günaltay forms the new government of Turkey. It is the 18th government, last single party government of the Republican People's Party.

January  – The first VW Type  to arrive in the United States, a  model, is brought to New York by Dutch businessman Ben Pon. Unable to interest dealers or importers in the Volkswagen, Pon sells the sample car to pay his travel expenses. Only two  models are sold in America that year, convincing Volkswagen chairman Heinrich Nordhoff the car has no future in the U.S. (The Type  goes on to become an automotive phenomenon.)
January  – The International Police Association (IPA) – the largest police organization in the world – is formed.

January  – Sverdlovsk plane crash: Aeroflot Lisunov Li- crashes in a snowstorm. All  aboard are killed, including almost the entire national ice hockey team (VVS Moscow) of the Soviet Air Force –  players, as well as a team doctor and a masseur.
January  – The United Kingdom recognizes the People's Republic of China; the Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Britain in response.
January  – A fire in the St Elizabeth's Ward of Mercy Hospital in Davenport, Iowa, United States, kills  patients.
January  – The Israeli government recognizes the People's Republic of China.
January  – Korean War: Third Battle of Seoul – Chinese and North Korean forces capture Seoul for the second time (having lost the Second Battle of Seoul in September ).
January  – The Government of the United Kingdom announces abandonment of the Tanganyika groundnut scheme for the cultivation of peanuts in the Tanganyika Territory, with the writing off of £.5M debt.

January  – In the U.S., a top secret report is delivered to U.S. President Truman by his National Security Resources Board, urging Truman to expand the Korean War by launching "a global offensive against communism" with sustained bombing of Red China and diplomatic moves to establish "moral justification" for a U.S. nuclear attack on the Soviet Union. The report will not be declassified until .
January  – In a criminal court in West Germany, Ilse Koch, The "Witch of Buchenwald", wife of the commandant of the Buchenwald concentration camp, is sentenced to life imprisonment.
January  – Winter of Terror: Avalanches in the Alps kill  and bury , for a time, in Switzerland, Austria and Italy.
January  - A Douglas C- Dakota operated by Aer Lingus crashes in Wales while flying from Northolt Royal Air Force Station to Dublin. All twenty-three occupants were killed.
January  – Black Saturday in Egypt: Rioters burn Cairo's central business district, targeting British and upper-class Egyptian businesses.

February 
Princess Elizabeth, Duchess of Edinburgh, becomes monarch of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and the British Dominions: Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, Pakistan and Ceylon. The princess, who is on a visit to Kenya when she hears of the death of her father, King George VI, aged , takes the regnal name Elizabeth II.
In the United States, a mechanical heart is used for the first time in a human patient.

January – – Finnish troops reoccupy Porkkala, after Soviet troops vacate its military base. Civilians can return February .

January  – The Huygens spacecraft lands on Titan, the largest moon of Saturn.
January – – Russia temporarily cuts shipment of natural gas to Ukraine during a price dispute.
January  – A stampede during the Stoning of the Devil ritual on the last day at the Hajj in Mina, Saudi Arabia, kills at least  pilgrims.
January  – NASA's Stardust mission successfully ends, the first to return dust from a comet.
January  – NASA launches the first interplanetary space probe to Pluto, the New Horizons.
January  – Evo Morales is inaugurated as president of Bolivia.

January 
Bulgaria and Romania join the European Union, while Slovenia joins the Eurozone.
Adam Air Flight , en route to Manado, Indonesia, from Surabaya, Indonesia, crashes into the Makassar Strait; killing all  on board.

January  – At :: UTC, the uncrewed MESSENGER space probe is at its closest approach during its first flyby of the planet Mercury.

January 
Stock markets around the world plunge amid growing fears of a U.S. Great Recession, fueled by the  subprime mortgage crisis.
Online activist group Anonymous initiates Project Chanology, after a leaked interview of Tom Cruise by the Church of Scientology is published on YouTube, and the Church of Scientology issued a "copyright infringement" claim. In response, Anonymous sympathizers took to the streets to protest outside the church (after February ), while the church's websites and centres were getting DoS attacks, phone line nukes, and black faxes.

January 
Japan, Mexico, Turkey and Uganda assume their seats on the United Nations Security Council.
Asunción, the capital of Paraguay, becomes the American Capital of Culture and Vilnius and Linz become the European Capitals of Culture.
Slovakia adopts the euro as its national currency, replacing the Slovak koruna.
A Bay Area Rapid Transit police officer shoots and kills Oscar Grant, an unarmed black man, at Fruitvale station in Oakland, United States. The event becomes one of the inciting incidents for the global Black Lives Matter movement.

January  – The tallest man-made structure to date, the Burj Khalifa in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, is officially opened.

January  – The Togo national football team is attacked in Cabinda Province, Angola, and as a result withdraws from the Africa Cup of Nations. The attack was perpetrated by the FLEC, their first since the Angolan Civil War.
January  – Religious violence erupts in Jos, Nigeria, which left scores dead, and many injured.
January  – A .-magnitude earthquake occurs in Haiti, devastating the nation's capital, Port-au-Prince.
January  – Yemen declares an open war against the terrorist group al-Qaeda.

January 
Estonia officially adopts the Euro currency and becomes the 17th Eurozone country.
A bomb explodes as Coptic Christians in Alexandria, Egypt leave a new year service, killing  people.

January  – Tunisian street vendor Mohamed Bouazizi dies after setting himself on fire a month earlier, sparking anti-government protests in Tunisia and later other Arab nations. These protests become known collectively as the Arab Spring.
January  – The Cicada  internet hunt begins.

January  – Peaceful protests begin in the Romanian city of Târgu Mureș, protesters expressing solidarity towards certain figures in the medical field and calling for the resignation of president Traian Băsescu. The protests would soon spread through all of the country, marking the start of a long civil unrest in Romania, lasting up to November .
January  – The passenger cruise ship Costa Concordia runs aground off the coast of Italy, causing  deaths.
January  – Iran–European Union relations: the European Union adopts an embargo against Iran in protest of its continued effort to enrich uranium.

February  – Egypt's deadliest football incident known as the Port Said Stadium riot is sparked after local Port Said Al Masry fans attack supporters of Cairo-based team Al Ahly SC. The massacre results in  deaths:  Al Ahly fans,  Al Masry fan and  police officer. Most of the deaths are caused by stabbing, fans thrown off the stands and a stampede.
January  –  Craig, Alaska earthquake: A Mw . (Ms ., 'Moderate') earthquake shakes Prince of Wales Island.
January  – At least  people are killed and  are injured in several bomb blasts in Pakistan.
January  – The French military begins a -month intervention into the Northern Mali conflict, targeting the militant Islamist Ansar Dine group.
January – –  international workers and  security guard die in a hostage crisis at a natural gas facility near In Aménas, Algeria.
January  – An estimated  people die in a nightclub fire in Santa Maria, Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil.
January  – Latvia adopts the euro as its currency and becomes the 18th member of the Eurozone.
January  – A launch of the communication satellite GSAT- aboard the GSLV Mk.II D5 marks the first successful flight of an Indian cryogenic rocket engine.

January  – The Elk River Chemical Spill in Charleston, West Virginia, when a leakage of the chemical MCMH from a Freedom Industries chemical plant left , residents of Charleston and nine surrounding counties without drinkable water for over three months.
February – The West African Ebola virus epidemic begins, infecting at least , people and killing at least , people, the most severe both in terms of numbers of infections and casualties.
February – – The XXII Olympic Winter Games are held in Sochi, Russia. Slopestyle events are introduced for the first time
January  – Lithuania officially adopts the euro as its currency, replacing the litas, and becomes the 19th Eurozone country.
January – – A series of massacres in Baga, Nigeria and surrounding villages by Boko Haram kills more than , people.

January  – Two gunmen belonging to Al-Qaeda's Yemen branch kill  people and injure  more at the Paris headquarters of satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, prompting an anti-terrorism demonstration attended by over a million people and more than  world leaders.
January  – A Boko Haram and Islamic State assault on Kolofata in the Far North Region of Cameroon is repelled by the Cameroonian Army, who kill  Boko Haram and Islamic State insurgents.
January  – The Swiss National Bank abandons the cap on the franc's value relative to the euro, causing turmoil in international financial markets.
January  – Following the fallout caused by the execution of Nimr al-Nimr, Saudi Arabia and several other countries end their diplomatic relations with Iran.
January  – Joaquín Guzmán, widely regarded as the world's most powerful drug trafficker, is recaptured following his escape from a maximum-security prison in Mexico.
January  – Ten people are killed and  wounded in a bombing near the Blue Mosque in Istanbul.

January 
The International Atomic Energy Agency announces that Iran has adequately dismantled its nuclear weapons program, allowing the United Nations to lift sanctions immediately.
 people are killed and  injured in terrorist attacks in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, targeting a hotel and a nearby restaurant. A siege occurs and  hostages are released afterwards, by government forces.
In the general election of the Republic of China (Taiwan), the Democratic Progressive Party, led by Tsai Ing-wen, secured a majority in the Legislative Yuan, resulting in the first majority by a non-KMT party and the first majority won by the DPP. Tsai became the 14th President for Taiwan, and also became the first female leader in China.

January  – Istanbul nightclub shooting: A gunman dressed as Santa Claus opens fire at the Reina nightclub in Istanbul, Turkey, killing  people and injuring  others.
January   –  Jerusalem truck attack: A Palestinian assailant entered the road where the Israeli defense forces were located with a truck, killing  people and injuring  others.

January  – Turkish Airlines Flight , a cargo flight en route from Hong Kong to Istanbul via Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, crashes in a residential area while attempting to land at Manas International Airport, Bishkek, killing all four crew members on board and  people on the ground.

January  – – Gambian constitutional crisis: The Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) launches a military intervention in the Gambia after Yahya Jammeh refuses to cede power following the  presidential elections.

January 
– Gambian constitutional crisis: Following the military intervention of ECOWAS, President Yahya Jammeh resigns from office after  years in power and flees into exile to Equatorial Guinea; the democratically elected Adama Barrow assumes office as President of The Gambia.
Millions of people worldwide join the Women's March following the inauguration of Donald Trump as President of the United States.  marches were reported in the U.S. and  in other countries, becoming the largest single-day protest in American history.
January  – Bulgaria takes over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union, after the Estonian presidency.
January  – SPLM-IO rebels loyal to Chan Garang Lual start a raid against Juba, capital of South Sudan.
January – – The first round of voting in the  Czech presidential election is held.

January  – Turkey, led by President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, announces the beginning of a military offensive to capture a portion of northern Syria from Kurdish forces, amidst the ongoing Kurdish–Turkish conflict.
January – – The US government enters a federal government shutdown as a result of a dispute over Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals.

January  – Supporters of US President Donald Trump attack the US Capitol, disrupting certification of the  presidential election, and forcing both houses of Congress to evacuate. Five people die during the ensuing riot. The event is classified as a domestic terrorist attack, and draws international condemnation.
January  – Sriwijaya Air Flight  crashes north of Jakarta, Indonesia, killing all  people on board.
January  – Kim Jong Un is elected as the General Secretary of the ruling Workers' Party of Korea, inheriting the title from his father Kim Jong Il, who died in .

January 
France takes over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union, after the Slovenian presidency.

January  – Croatia adopts the euro and joins the Schengen Area, becoming the 20th member state of the Eurozone and the 27th member of the Schengen Area. This is the first enlargement of the Eurozone since Lithuania's entry in , and the first enlargement of the Schengen Area since Liechtenstein's entry in .
